title: ngeru
desc:
Māku ngā ngeru e whāngai!
I will feed the cats!
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

E kimihia ana te kiore e te ngeru.
The cat is searching for the rat.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

Some other words for ngeru are naki, poti, tori and puihi.

title: waho
desc:
Kei waho te ngeru.
The cat is outside.
- this is an example of a locative sentence
Kei waho te kurī i te whare.
The dog is outside the house.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

title: mātakitaki(na)
desc: Ka mātakitakina te ngeru e te kurī. The cat will be watched by the dog. - this is an example of a passive sentence E mātakitaki ana te ngeru ki te manu.The cat is watching the bird.- this is an example of an active sentence

title: ātaahua
desc:
Tō ātaahua hoki!
You’re so beautiful!


He ātaahua tērā ngeru!
That’s a beautiful cat!
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: tungāne
desc:
He kaha tōku tungāne.
My brother is strong.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

Note that this is a term that a female speaker would use to refer to her brother.  To refer to his brother (or male cousins), a male speaker would use the terms tuakana (elder sibling) or teina (younger sibling).  These two terms may also be used by female speakers to refer to their sisters and female cousins.

Alternatively, speakers of either sex might use the terms mātāmua (eldest) or pōtiki (youngest).  

A male speaker may use tungāne to refer to the brother of a woman, for example,

Ko te tungāne o Ngaire ia.
He is Ngaire’s brother.

title: pōtiki
desc:
Pōtiki means youngest in the family. For example,

He nauhea iti tōku pōtiki!
My youngest child is a little rascal.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

This term may be used by a male or female speaker.

title: tama
desc: Ko Tai tāku tama.Tai is my son.- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: pango
desc:
E kihi ana ia i tētahi ngeru pango.
She is kissing a black cat.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: tamāhine
desc: Ko Indya tāku tamāhine.Indya is my daughter.- this is an example of an equative sentenceTo refer to one's step-daughter, use tamāhine whakaangi.

title: mā
desc:
Kua mā katoa koe!
You are completely clean!
- this is an example of a stative sentence

Ka horoia ngā kākahu mā e ia.
The white clothes will be washed by him.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: kurī
desc: He kino tēnei kurī.This dog is bad.- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: manu
desc:
Kei runga te manu i te whare.
The bird is on the house.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

title: ika
desc:
Ka kai tātou i tētahi ika nui. 
We will eat a big fish. 
- this is an example of an active sentence
Te Ūpoko o te Ika a Māui
The head of the fish of Māui (a name for the Wellington region).
See also hī ika - to fish.

title: kiore
desc: E kimi ana te ngeru ki te kiore.The cat is searching for the mouse.- this is an example of an active sentence

title: hoiho
desc:
E kauhoe ana te hoiho i te moana.The yellow-eyed penguin is swimming in the sea.- this is an example of an active sentence
Other names for penguin are:

    kororā - little blue penguin
    pokotiwha - drooping crested penguin

title: pākākā
desc:
He makawe pākākā ō te wahine e waiata ana.
The woman singing has brown hair.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

Other words for brown include parāone, parāuri.

title: kōwhai
desc:
Kōwhai means yellow or refers to the Kōwhai tree.
He kōwhai te rā.
The sun is yellow.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: karaka
desc:
He hū karaka ōna!
He has some orange shoes!
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: matua / mātua
desc:
Ko Hone tōku matua.
Hone is my father.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

Ko Barry rāua ko Lynne ōku mātua.
Barry and Lynne are my parents.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: wao
desc:
Kei roto ngā rākau i te wao.There are trees in the forest.
'Wao' meaning 'forest' is an archaic term which comes from Te Wao Tapu Nui ā Tāne Mahuta - 'the great forest of Tāne Mahuta'. 
This is a locative phrase which describes the location of something.  A locative phrase is made up of:
A tense marker = Kei (present tense) 
A location/locative noun = Roto (in)
A Subject = Rākau (tree) which is marked by a 'definite article' nga (the plural form of 'te' meaning 'the' which signifies the plural form of 'rākau' (trees)
An object marker = i
An object = Wao (Forest)

title: kōwhai (plant)
desc:
The kōwhai shrub or tree has yellow flowers.  Kōwhai also means yellow.
He kōwhai tērā rakau.That tree is a kōwhai.

title: Kohi-tātea
desc:
I tērā Kohi-tātea i noho mātou ki tātahi.In January we (3 exclusive of listener) stayed at the seaside.- this is an example of an active sentence
Another name for January is Hānuere.

title: Poutū-te-rangi
desc:
I tīmata au i tēnei mahi i te whā o ngā rā o Poutū-te-rangi.
I started this work on the 4th (day) of March.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Another name for March is Māehe.

title: Hui-tanguru
desc:
Ka hoki mai tātou ā tēnei Hui-tanguru.We will return in February.- this is an example of an active sentence
Another name for February is Pēpuere.

title: Paenga-whāwhā
desc:
Kua oti te hangaiatanga o te waka ā tēnei Paenga-whāwhā.
The waka will be finished in April.
- this is an example of a stative sentence
Another name for April is Āperira.

title: Haratua
desc:
I hoko tōku whaea i ngā rōhi i tērā Haratua.My mother bought the roses in May.- this is an example of an active sentence
Another name for May is Mei.

title: Pipiri
desc:
Pipiri is a name for the month of June. 
Ia Pipiri, tīmata ai te hukapapa. In June, the frosts usually start. 
Pipiri also means 'cling together' due to the cold.
Another name for June is Hune.

title: Mahuru
desc:
E noho ana au ki konei atu ki te marama ā Mahuru.
I'm staying here until the month of September.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Another name for September is Hepetema.

title: Hōngongoi
desc:
He marama pai a Hōngongoi kia kokotia ngā rōhi. 
July is a good month to prune the roses. 
- this is an example of a classifying sentence 

Me kokoti ngā rōhi i a Hōngongoi. 
The roses should be pruned in July. 
Another name for July is Hūrae.

title: Here-turi-kōkā
desc:
Ā te marama o Here-turi-kōkā ka haere mātou ki Ruapehu ki te whakareti.We (3 exclusive) will go to Ruapehu to ski in August. - this is an example of an active sentence 
Another name for August is Ākuhata.

title: Whiringa-ā-nuku
desc:
Ka ātaahua te māra ā tēnei Whiringa-ā-nuku.
The garden will be beautiful in October.
- this is an example of a stative sentence
Another name for October is Oketopa.

title: Hakihea
desc:
I te marama o Hakihea, i terea e mātou mai i te Whanganui-a-Tara atu ki Akaroa.In December, we (3+ exclusive) sailed from Wellington to Akaroa.- this is an example of a passive sentence
Another name for December is Tīhema.

title: Whiringa-ā-rangi
desc:
Ka hoki mai au ā tēnei Whiringa-ā-rangi. I will return this November.- this is an example of an active sentence
Another name for November is Noema.

title: Rātapu
desc:
Kaua e wareware tā tātou hui ā tēnei Rātapu.
Don't forget our meeting this Sunday.
- this is an example use of Kaua e - Do not

Rātapu - day of worship - a Pākehā concept translated accordingly.

title: Rāhina
desc:
Ka haere rāua ki tāwāhi ā tēnei Rāhina.
They're going overseas on Monday.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Monday honours the moon; Rāhina comes from Māhina - an ancient name for the moon.

Another name for Monday is Mane.

title: Rātū
desc:
Ā tērā Rātū ka peka atu au ki Ōtepoti kia kite ai i ōku mātua.
Next Tuesday I'll call in to Dunedin to see my parents.
- this example uses "ai" to indicate purpose
Rātū honours Tūmatauenga (Mars).
Another name for Tuesday is Tūrei.

title: i
kupu_ingarihi: by, due to (in stative sentences only); preposition, past time and place location - at, in
desc:
Kua mahue au i te pahi.
I have been left behind by the bus.
- this is an example of a stative sentence
I hea koe?
Where were you?
- this example uses hea to ask where

I Disneyland au!
I was in Disneyland!
- this is an example of a locative sentence

title: Rāapa
desc:
Ia Rāapa ia Rāapa waea ai tāku tamāhine ki a au.
Every Wednesday my daughter phones me.
- this example uses "ai" for customary action

Also see ia rā, ia rā.

Rāapa honours Apārangi (Mercury).

Another name for Wednesday is Wenerei.

title: mārama
desc:
Kua mārama koe ki te pātai? 
Have you understood the question? 
- this is an example of an active sentence
Kua mārama au ki tōu whakautu.
I've understood your response.  
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: mokemoke
desc: I mokemoke ia i te ngaro o tō māua hoa.He's lonely as a result of the absence of our (2 inclusive) friend.- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: mate
kupu_ingarihi: to be dead, to be sick
desc:
Kua mate tō tātou mea kahurangi.
Our precious one has passed away.
- this is an example of a stative sentence

Ka mate koe i te kai hikareti.
You will become dead/sick by smoking. (Smoking causes death/sickness.)
- this is an example of a stative sentence
Another word for sick is māuiui.

title: hinga
desc: Kua hinga te tōtara i te tangata.The tōtara has fallen due to the man.- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: mutu
desc:
Kua mutu tāku mahi i a au.
My work has been finished by me. (I've stopped working)
- this is an example of a stative sentence 

Oti is used in preference to mutu when there is a sense of completion. If the work had been completely finished we would use oti.

title: māngere
desc:
E māngere ana ngā tamariki i te pouaka whakaata.
The television is making the children lazy.
- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: ngaro
kupu_ingarihi: to be missing, to be absent
desc: Kua ngaro te ngeru i te kōtiro.The cat has become missing because of the girl.- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: mahue
desc: Kua mahue ia i te pahi.He has been left behind by the bus.- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: wareware
desc: Kua wareware te parāoa i a ia.He has forgotten the bread. (The bread was forgotten by him.)- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: kī
desc:
Kua kī tō puku?
Is your tummy full?
- this is an example of a stative sentence

Kua kī te wharekai i ngā tangata katoa.
The restaurant has been filled by all the people.
- this is an example of a stative sentence

Kua kī tōku puku.
My tummy is full.
- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: hū
desc:
Kua hū ngā kōura i a Tama.
The crayfish have been boiled by Tama.
- this is an example of a stative sentence

Wetekina ō hū.
Take off your shoes.
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form

title: reri
desc:
Kua reri te kai!.
The food is ready!
- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: tata
desc: Kua tata te kai te reri.The food is nearly ready.- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: riro
desc:
Kua riro te mahi uaua i a au.The hard work has been received by me.- this is an example of a stative sentence 
Whiwhi is another word meaning received but it is not a stative. Riro is preferred to whiwhi when you're stuck with the result! You would probably whiwhi a book.

title: mātaotao
desc: Kua mātaotao te inu pia i te pouaka makariri.The beer has been cooled by the fridge.- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: oti
kupu_ingarihi: to be complete, to be finished
desc:
I oti te hangaiatanga o te whare i ngā tāngata hanga whare.
The building of the house has been completed by the builders.
- this is an example of a stative sentence 
Oti is used in preference to mutu when there is a sense of completion. If the builders had finished for the day and were to return tomorrow, we would use mutu.

title: hora
desc:
Kua hora ngā kai i a Manu.
The food has been spread out by Manu.
- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: tūreiti
desc: Kua tūreiti au i te pahi.I have been made late by the bus.- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: pau
kupu_ingarihi: to be consumed, to be used up
desc:
Kua pau te wai i a Kiri.
Kiri has consumed the water.
- this is an example of a stative sentence 

He maha ngā moni kua pau i a ia i te toa.
She has spent lots of money at the shop.

title: whati
desc: Kua whati te rakau i tāku waewae.The stick has been snapped by my foot.- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: pakaru
desc: Kua pakaru te kapu i te tangata kino.The cup has been broken by the bad man.- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: Rāpare
desc:
I ngā Rāpare, mātakitaki ai au i Coronation Street.
On Thursdays I watch Coronation Street.
- this example uses "ai" for customary action

Rāpare honours Pareārau (Jupiter).

Another name for Thursday is Tāite.

title: Rāhoroi
desc:
I horoia ngā kākahu e au i tērā Rāhoroi.
The clothes were washed by me on Saturday.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

Rāhoroi - washing day.

Another name for Saturday is Hātarei.

title: Rāmere
desc:
Ā tērā Rāmere, ka haere māua ki Temuka.
Next Friday, we (2 exclusive) will go to Temuka.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Rāmere honours Meremere (Venus).

Another name for Friday is Paraire.

title: i ētahi wā
desc:
I ētahi wā, ka haere au ki te mahi.
Sometimes I go to work.
- this is an example of an active sentence
This kīwaha can also be placed at the end of the sentence.

title: i ngā wā katoa
desc: Kei te moe tāku ngeru i ngā wā katoa!My cat sleeps all the time!- this is an example of an active sentence

title: engari
desc:
Kei te hiakai au, engari, kore kau he kai!
I am starving, but, there is absolutely no food!

Kei te pai au, engari kei te tangi ia.
I’m ok, but she’s crying.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: nā te mea
desc:
E ruku pāua ana au nā te mea e haere mai ana tōku hungarei.
I'm going pāua diving because my mother-in-law is coming.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: ia rā, ia rā
desc:
Ia rā, ia rā, tunu ai au i te hapa.
Every day, (each day) I cook dinner.
Rā (day) can be replaced with any word appropriate to the context: wiki (week), marama (month), tau (year), Rāapa (Wednesday), etc.
Repetition like this is often used for emphasis.

title: mehemea
desc:
Mehemea ka haere koe, ka haere au hoki.
If you go, I'll go too.
Other words for if include inā and mēnā.

title: kātahi te...
desc: Kātahi te kurī pai!What a good dog!

title: ā
desc:
Inanahi, i haere au ki te toa ki te hoko i te paraoa, ā, i haere au ki te kura ki te ako.
Yesterday, I went to the shop to buy bread and I went to school to learn.
However, in Maori, the above Māori sentence would still have the English translation (with and) without the co-ordinating conjunction ā. It seems that ā is being used increasingly due to the influence of English.

title: me (conjunction)
desc:
As apposed to the conjunction ā, me is used as a conjunction for two objects/things as apposed to two sentences.  Note the differences in the following sentences: 
Inanahi, I haere au ki te toa ki te hoko i te paraoa me te miraka, ā, i haere au ki te kura ki te ako.
I went to the shop to buy the bread and the milk, and I went to school to learn.
me is co-ordinating the two object/things (bread and milk) whereas ā is co-ordinating two sentences.

title: i tērā (wiki/tau)
desc:
I kōrero au i tōku whaea i tērā wiki.
I spoke to my mother last week.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: i tēnei (marama/rā)
desc:
I tēnei rā, i haere au ki te mahi mā runga pāhikara.
Today I went to work by bicycle.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: inatahirā
desc:
Inatahirā, i haere au ki te mahi mā runga hoiho.
The day before yesterday, I went to work on horseback.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: āpōpō
desc:
Āpōpō, ka haere au ki te kura.
Tomorrow, I will go to school.
- this is an example of an active sentence
It is possible to place āpōpō at the end of the sentence too.  
Ka haere au ki te kura, āpōpō.
I will go to school tomorrow.

Ka hoki mai au āpōpō.
I will return tomorrow.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: ki tōku nei mōhio
desc: Ki tōku nei mōhio, ka tīmata te ua ākuanei.To my knowledge, it will start raining soon.

title: ko te āhua nei
desc:
Ko te āhua nei, kei te heke te ua.It appears as if the rain is falling.
Also see me te mea nei.

title: ātahirā
desc:
Ātahirā ka haere mātou ki tāwāhi.
The day after tomorrow we (3+excl) will go overseas.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: tēnā
desc:
He pukapuka tēnā.That (by you) is a book.
(HE + NOUN + DEFINITE ARTICLE)
tēnā is a definite article

title: tēnei
desc:
He pukapuka tēnei. This (by me) is a book. (HE + NOUN + DEFINITE ARTICLE) tēnei is a definite article
This example shows the use of a definite article (tēnei) in an indefinite sentence.

title: tērā
desc:
He pukapuka tērā.
That (over there/at a distance) is a book.
(HE + NOUN + DEFINITE ARTICLE)
tērā is a definite article

title: te
desc:
te is a definite article 
Ko te pukapuka. The book (singular - only 1 book). (KO + DEFINITE ARTICLE + NOUN)Ko te tāne au!I am the man!   KO + DEFINITE ARTICLE + NOUN + PRONOUN 
Ko te wahine au!I am the woman!KO + DEFINITE ARTICLE + NOUN + PRONOUN 
I haere ia ki te toa.He went to the shop. - this is an example of an active sentence

title: ngā
desc:
Ko ngā pukapuka.The books (plural - more than 1 book)
(KO + DEFINITE ARTICLE + NOUN)
ngā is a definite article Ka korero au ki ngā tamariki.I spoke to the children.- this is an example of an active sentence

title: ēnei
desc:
Ko ngā pukapuka ēnei.These (by me) are the books.
(KO + DEFINITE ARTICLE + NOUN + DEFINITE ARTICLE)
Note when we use a definite sentence and if we use a plural definite article such as ēnei we must also use the plural definite article ngā meaning 'the'.  (As above).
ēnei is a definite article

title: ēnā
desc:
He pukapuka ēnā.Those are books (by you).
ēnā is a definite article

title: ērā
desc:
He pukapuka ērā.
Those (over there/at a distance) are some books.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence
ēra is a definite article

title: ia
desc:
Ka haere ia.She/he will go.
We learn from context whether the pronoun refers to male or female.

title: māua
desc:
Ka haere māua.
We (2, excluding the listener) will go.
Scenario:  Tama and Mere are going to go.  They tell Whaea Mahinaarangi that they are going to go.  Tama says "E Whaea, Ka haere māua" which mean "Whaea we (2 excl) will go".  Whaea knows that it is Tama and Mere that are going not Tama and Whaea, as Tama used the exclusive pronoun for two people, māua.

title: mātou
desc:
Ka haere mātou.We (3 people, exclusive of listener) are going.
Scenario: Tama, Mere, and Tahi are going. Tama tells Whaea Mahinaarangi that they are going.  He says "E Whaea, Ka haere mātou" which means "Whaea, we (3 excl) are going." Whaea knows that it is Tama, Mere and Tahi that are going and not Whaea, because he used the exclusive pronoun for 3 people which does not include the listener (Whaea).

title: tāua
desc:
Ka haere tāua.We (2 people, inclusive of listener) will go.
Scenario:  Tama and Mere are going.  Tama goes to tell Mere that they will go.  He says "E Mere, Ka haere tāua" which means "Mere, we (2 incl) will go".  Mere knows that it is Tama and her going, as Tama used the inclusive pronoun for 2 people tāua.

title: tātou
kupu_ingarihi: we (3 or more people) inclusive of listener
desc:
Ka haere tātou.We (3 people, inclusive of listener) will go.
Scenario:  Tama, Mere AND Whaea Mahinaarangi are going to go.  Tama goes to tell Whaea that they will all go, including Whaea.  He says "E Whaea, Ka haere tātou" which means "Whaea, we (3+ inclusive of listener) will go".  Whaea knows that she is going with Tama and Mere because Tama used the inclusive pronoun for 3 or more people tātou.

title: rāua
desc:
Ka haere rāua.They (2 people) will go.  
Scenario:  Tama and Mere are going to go.  Whaea goes to tell Koro that they will go.  She says "E Koro, Ka haere rāua" which means "Koro, they (2) will go" Koro knows that Whaea is talking about Tama and Mere because she used the exclusive of listener and speaker pronoun for 2 people rāua.

title: rātou
desc:
Ka haere rātou.They (3 or more people) will go.
Scenario:  Tama, Mere and Tahi are going.  Whaea goes to tell Koro that they will go.  She says "E Koro, Ka haere rātou" which means "Koro, they (3 or more people) will go."  Koro knows that Whaea is talking about Tama, Mere and Tahi because she used the exclusive of listener and speaker pronoun for 3 or more people rātou.

title: hoe(a)
desc:
Nā Manu te waka i hoe ki te motu.
Manu paddled the boat to the island.
- this is an example of the agent emphatic
I hoea te waka e ngā manuhiri ki te motu.
The boat was paddled by the guests to the island.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: titiro (tirohia)
desc:
Kei te titiro au ki te tamaiti e menemene mai ana.
I am looking at the child who is smiling at me.
- this is an example of an active sentence
- this example includes a relative clause

titiro usually takes ‘ki’ rather than ‘i’ – it does occur with ‘i’ and means to look at closely, to study.

Kua tirohia ngā tāonga e ngā tauira.
The artefacts have been looked at by the students.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: tango(hia)
desc:
Kua tango au i ōku hū.
I have removed my shoes.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Kua tangohia nā hū e tōnā matua.
His shoes have been removed by his father.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: neke(hia)
desc:
Kei te neke au mai i Te Whanganui-ā-Tara atu ki Te Karu o te Ika.I am moving from Wellington to Wairarapa.- this is an example of an active sentence
E nekehia ana ngā pouaka e ngā tamariki.The boxes are being moved by the children.- this is an example of a passive sentenceHe ua ake te nekehanga.The shift was difficult.
Nekehia ki Te Karu o te Ika!Move to Wairarapa!

title: hari(a)
desc:
Kua haria ngā pouaka e au.The boxes have been carried by me.- this is an example of a passive sentence
Kua hari au i ngā pouaka.I have carried the boxes.- this is an example of an active sentence
Ka haria ngā tamariki e au ki te papa tākaro.The children will be taken by me to the playground.- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: menemene
desc: Kei te menemene mai te pēpi.The baby is smiling at me.- this is an example of an active sentence

title: oma
desc:
E oma, e te tau!
Run, my darling!
- this is an example of a command in simple active form

title: kōrero(tia)
desc:
I kōrero te koroua ki tāna tahu.
The old man spoke to his love.
- this is an example of an active sentence
kōrero always takes 'ki' rather than 'i'.
Kua kōrerotia te tamaiti e tōna kaiako.
The child has been spoken to by his/her teacher.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
Ka kōrero ia ki te kuramāhita. 
She will speak to the headmaster. 
- this is an example of an active sentence

Kei te kōrerotia ia e te kuramāhita. 
She is being spoken to by the headmaster 
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: hīkoi
desc:
Ka hīkoi mātou ki pāremata.
We (3+excl) will walk to parliament.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: tangi(hia)
desc:
Kaua e tangi, e te tau.
Don’t cry my darling.
- this is an example of a command using Kaua e

Kei te tangi te pēpi.
The baby is crying.
- this is an example of an active sentence 

Kei te tangi te koroua i tōna tahu.
The old man is mourning his love.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Kua tangihia te mate e te tini.
The deceased is being mourned by many.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: noho
desc:
Kia tika te noho, e te tau.
Sit properly, my darling.


Kei te tēpu ngā tamariki e noho ana.
The children are sitting at the table.
- this is an example of an active sentence


Kei te Whanganui-ā-Tara au e noho ana.
I am living in Wellington.
- this is an example of an active sentence


E noho rā.
Stay well (Goodbye).


Use this farewell when you are the person leaving.
(Compare ‘haere rā’)

Noho ora mai.
Stay/keep well.

title: patu(a)
desc:
I patua te rango e te tangata.The fly was hit by the man.- this is an example of a passive sentence
Ka patu au i te pōro.I will hit the ball.- this is an example of an active sentence

title: kai(nga)
desc:
E kai ana te pēpi i ngā rīwai. 
The baby is eating the potatoes. 
- this is an example of an active sentence 

E kainga ana ngā rīwai e te pēpi. 
The potatoes are being eaten by the baby. 
- this is an example of a passive sentence 

Kainga tāu āporo! 
Eat your apple!
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form 

He kai pai te kūmara. 
Kumara is good food. (Kumara is good/healthy food.) 
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: pānui(tia)
desc:
He pai ki a koe te pānui pukapuka?
Do you like to read books?
- this is an example of a classifying sentence
{QuestionTone}


Kāore ia i pānui i tāna mahi-ā-kāinga. 
He didn’t read his homework. 
- this is a negative verbal sentence

Nā te rangatira taua īmēra i pānui. 
It was the boss who read that (aforementioned) email. 
- this is an example of the agent emphatic 

Kei hea ngā pānui mō tēnei ahiahi? 
Where are the notices for this afternoon? 
- this example uses hea to ask where 

Kāore anō tēnei pānui kia pānuitia e au. 
I have not yet read this notice. (This notice has not yet been read by me.) 
- this is a negative verbal sentence 

Kua pānuitia taua pukapuka e au. 
I have read that (aforementioned) book. (That aforementioned book has been read by me.) 
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: whiti(a)
desc:
E whiti ana te rā.
The sun is shining.
- this is an example of an active sentence

E whitia ana au e te rā.
I am being shone on by the sun.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

Kei te whiti te rā.
The sun is shining.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Haria ngā kākahu ki waho kia whitia ai e te rā. 
Take the clothes outside so that they can be shone on by the sun.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
- this example uses "ai" to indicate purpose

title: aroha(ina,tia)
desc:
Ka nui taku aroha mōu, e te tau!
I love you very much, my darling!


Kei te aroha te whaea ki tāna tamaiti.
The mother loves her child.
- this is an example of an active sentence

aroha always takes ‘ki’ rather than ‘i’.

Kei te arohaina te tamaiti e tōna whaea.
The child is loved by his mother.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

Arohatia te reo!
Love the language!
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form

title: tatari / tāria
desc:
Tatari mai i konā, e te tau.
Wait there, my darling.
- this is an example of a command in simple active form


Ka tatari au ki a koe.
I will wait for you.
- this is an example of an active sentence

tatari always takes 'ki' rather than 'i'.

Kua tāria koe e au.
You have been waited for by me.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: mōhio(tia)
desc:
Kei te mōhio ngā tauira ki te reo Māori. 
The students know the Māori language. 
- this is an example of an active sentence 

mōhio always takes ‘ki’ rather than ‘i’.

E mōhiotia whānuitia ana a Parekura Horomia e ngā tāngata Māori o te motu. 
Parekura Horomia is widely known by Māori people from all over. 
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: kākāriki
desc:
E moe ana au i tētahi rākau kākāriki.
I am sleeping in a green tree.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Two other words for green are kouru and pāpango.

Kākāriki is also the name for a New Zealand parakeet. 
more information on the bird

title: haere
desc:
Ka haere ngā tangata ki te awa.The people will go to the river.- this is an example of an active sentence
Haere mai!Welcome!Come here!
Haere atu!Go! (away)

title: whero
desc:
Hōmai tēnā pene whero.
Give me that red pen (by you).

title: māwhero
desc:
Nō wai ēnei hū māwhero?
To whom do these pink shoes belong?

title: waiporoporo
desc:
Nōu tēnei kōti waiporoporo?
Does this purple coat belong to you? 

Another word for purple is pāpura.

title: kikorangi
desc:
He kikorangi tōna whare.
His house is sky blue.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

Other words for blue are kahurangi and purū.

title: mahi(a)
desc:
E haere ana au ki te mahi. 
I am going to work. 
- this is an example of an active sentence 

I mahi tahi tātou katoa. 
We all worked together. 
- this is an example of an active sentence
Kua mahia te mahi pai e kōrua. 
You two have done a good job. (The good work has been done by you two.) 
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: kahurangi
desc:
E hiahia ana au ki tērā kākahu kahurangi.
I want that blue dress.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Other words for blue include kikorangi and purū.

title: tuakana
desc:
Ko Margaret tōku tuakana.Margaret is my older sister.- this is an example of an equative sentence
The above can be assumed to be spoken by a woman or girl. If a man were to talk of his sister Margaret, he would have said "Ko Margaret tōku tuahine."

title: teina
desc:
Ko Pania tōku teina.
Pania is my younger sister.
- this is an example of an equative sentence
This can be assumed to have been spoken by a woman or girl. If a man had referred to his sister he would have said "Ko Pania tōku tuahine."

title: tuahine
desc:
Ko Pania tōku tuahine.
Pania is my sister.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: runga
desc:
Kei runga tāu pene whero i tōu tēpu tari.
Your red pen is on your desk.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

runga is also used to indicate means of transport, for example:
Ka haere au ki te mahi mā runga pahikara.
I will go to work by bicycle.

or
I tae mai ia mā runga hoiho. 
He arrived on horse back. 
but
I tae mai ia mā raro.
He arrived on foot.

title: raro
desc:
Kei raro te ngeru i te tōtara.
The cat is under the tōtara tree.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

mā raro means on foot.
I tae mai ia mā raro.
He arrived on foot.
But
I tae mai ia mā runga hoiho. 
He arrived on horse back.

title: roto
desc:
Kei roto a Kahurangi rāua ko Hōhepa i tō rāua whare.
Kahurangi and Hōhepa are inside their house.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

title: mua
desc:
I mua ia i te toa.
He was in front of the shop.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

mua can be used to describe relationships in time, for example, 
I mahi kai mātou i mua i te hui.
We prepared food before the meeting.

title: muri
desc:
I muri tēnei pukapuka i te tūru.
This book was behind the chair.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

Muri can also be used to express relationships in time, for example,
I muri i te hui, i kōrero au ki a Manu.
After the meeting, I spoke with Manu.

title: au, ahau
desc:
Kei te mokemoke au.
I am lonely.
- this is an example of a stative sentence

au and ahau are interchangeable, except that in cases where we would write a au, the a is omitted if ahau is used, for example,

Kei te titiro ia ki a au.
Kei te titiro ia ki ahau. 
He's looking at me.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: koe
desc:
Kei te pēhea koe?
How are you?
koe is only used for second person singular, that is, to refer to one person. To say you when refering to two people, use kōrua, and use koutou if referring to three or more people.

title: kōrua
desc: Ko wai kōrua?Who are you two?

title: koutou
desc: Kia ora koutou!Hello you (3+)!

title: uta
desc:
Taihoa! Kei uta ngā ika.
Hold up! The fish are towards the land.
- this is an example of a locative sentence
Hoea ki uta!
Paddle towards the land!
See also tai - seaward.
Also note uta(ina) means to be loaded.

title: tātahi
desc:
I tērā Rāhoroi, i haere rātou ki tātahi kohi pipi ai.
On Saturday, they went to the beach to gather pipi.
- this example uses "ai" to indicate purpose 
Note that there is no te before tātahi as it is used the same way as other locative nouns e.g., runga, raro, etc.

title: tai
desc:
Kei tai ngā ika.
The fish are seaward.
- this is an example of a locative sentence
Ka hoe atu ngā tāngata i uta ki tai.
The people will paddle from the shore towards the sea.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Also see uta - ashore.

title: tawhiti
desc:
Kei tawhiti taku tahu.My beloved is far away.- this is an example of a locative sentence
Kua tae mai rāua i tawhiti.They (2) have arrived from afar.- this is an example of an active sentence

title: tāwāhi
desc:
Kei tāwāhi ia.
She is overseas.
- this is an example of a locative sentence
Ka haere atu ia ki tāwāhi.
She will go overseas.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: reira
kupu_ingarihi: there, the aforementioned place or time
desc:
I noho au i reira i tērā tau.
I stayed there last year.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: konei
kupu_ingarihi: here, this place (near to or in conection to the speaker)
desc:
Haere mai ki konei!
Come here! (to this place/to where i am)
- this is an example of a command in simple active form

title: korā
kupu_ingarihi: over there, yonder, that place or there abouts (away from the speaker and listener)
desc:
Ko wai tērā ki korā?
Who is that over there?
- this example uses wai to ask who

Ko tō tāne!
It’s your husband!   
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: konā
kupu_ingarihi: there, that place or thereabouts (by the person spoken to)
desc:
Kei hea tāku mōkai kurī?
Where’s my pet dog?
- this example uses hea to ask where

Kei konā, kei tōu kāinga.
There (by you) at your place. 
- this is an example of a locative sentence

title: waenganui
desc:
He aha kei waenganui i te rūma noho?
What’s in the middle of the lounge?
- this example uses he aha to ask what

He tēpu kāwhi kei waenganui i te rūma noho.
There’s a coffee table in the middle of the lounge.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

Kei waenganui āu kī i te tūru me te waea pūkoro.
Your keys are between the chair and the cell phone.

title: kaukau
desc:
I kaukau ngā tamariki i te whanga.
The children bathed (swam) in the bay.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Also see kauhoe - to swim.

E mōhio ana koe ki te kaukau?
Do you know how to swim?
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: kauhoe
desc:
I kauhoe atu ia ki te motu.
He swam to the island.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Also see kaukau - to bathe.

title: mahana
desc:
Kei te mahana te wai?
Is the water warm?
- this is an example of an active sentence

Auē! Ka mahana haere te kaimoana i te rā.
Oh dear! The seafood is getting warm in the sun.
- this is an example of a stative sentence

whakamahana means to warm, for example,
Ka whakamahana au i te kai.
I will warm the food.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: tākaro(hia)
desc:
Ka tākaro ngā tamariki ki waho. 
The children will play outside. 
- this is an example of an active sentence
Kua tākarohia e mātou ngā kēmu e rua. 
We’ve played two games. 
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: ruku(hia)
desc:
Kei te ruku pāua a Manu.
Manu is diving for pāua.
- this is an example of an active sentence

I ruku ngā kōtiro ki roto i ngā ngaru.
The girls plunged into the waves.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Haere mai e tama, rukuhia ngā pāua a Tangaroa nei.
Come here son, dive for the pāua belonging to Tangaroa.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
- this is an example of using "a" possession

title: one
desc:
Ka moe rāua i te one.
They (2) are going to sleep on the beach.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Also see tātahi - seaside.

title: kohi(a)
desc:
Ka kohi au i te kaimoana.
I will collect sea food.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Ka kohi pipi au.
I will go pipi gathering.
- this is an example of an active sentence

I kohia ngā pipi e au.
I gathered the pipi.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: makariri
desc:
He tino makariri te moana.
The sea is very cold.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence
Makariri is also a name for winter.

title: ngaru
desc:
E kauhoe ana rātou i ngā ngaru.
They are swimming in the waves.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: hī ika
desc:
E hī ika ana au ki tātahi.
I'm going to go fishing at the beach. 
- this is an example of an active sentence

Kua utaina ngā matau me te aho e ia ki runga i te waka kia hī ika ai. 
The fish hooks and fishing line were loaded by him onto the waka in order to fish. 
- this is an example of a passive sentence
- this example uses "ai" to indicate purpose

See also ika - fish.

title: kaimoana
desc:
He pai rawa atu te kaimoana ki a ia.
She really likes seafood. (Literally “Seafood is best to her.”)
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: puta(ina)
desc: Kātahi tonu ia ka puta mai i te whare.Just then he appeared from the house.

title: whiwhi
desc:
I whiwhi ia i te karahipi.He received the scholarship.- this is an example of an active sentence
Riro is another word meaning received but it is a stative verb. Riro is preferred to whiwhi when you're stuck with the result! You would probably whiwhi a book. Either could be used for a scholarship.

title: whai (whāia)
kupu_ingarihi: to follow, to chase, to pursue
desc:
E whai ana ngā tamariki i te pōro. 
The children are chasing the ball. 
- this is an example of an active sentence 

Kei te whāia te pōro e ngā tamariki. 
The ball is being chased by the children. 
- this is an example of a passive sentence 

Whāia te mātauranga! 
Pursue education! 
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form

title: pupuri (puritia)
desc:
Puritia ngā taha o te waka kei taka koe!
Hold on to the sides of the waka lest you fall!
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form

title: eke
desc: Ka eke au ki runga i te pahi.I will mount the bus.- this is an example of an active sentence

title: whakakā(ngia)
kupu_ingarihi: to turn on, to light (a fire etc.)
desc: Whakakāngia mai ngā rāiti!Turn on the lights!

title: tākai(a)
desc: Kua tākaia te koha ki te pepa ātaahua nei.The present has been wrapped in this beautiful paper.- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: whakarongo
desc:
Whakarongo mai, e te tau!
Listen, here my darling!
- this is an example of a command in simple active form


E whakarongo ana māua ko Paora ki te tumuaki. 
Paora and I are listening to the head-master. 
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: moutere, motu
desc:
E kauhoe ana ia ki te moutere.
She is going to swim to the island.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: ringaringa
desc:
Horoia ō ringaringa.
Wash your hands
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form

title: hiahia(tia)
desc:
E hiahia ana ahau ki te ako i te reo Māori.
I want to learn Māori. 
- this is an example of an active sentence
hiahia always takes ‘ki’ rather than ‘i’.

title: pīrangi(tia)
desc:
E pīrangi ana a Māui ki tēnā aihikirimi. 
Māui desires/wants that icecream by you. 
- this is an example of an active sentence

pīrangi always takes ‘ki’ rather than ‘i’.

title: Pā(ngia)
desc:
Kua pāngia taua wahine e te mate. That woman has been sick. (That woman has been touched by sickness.)- this is an example of a passive sentence
Kei te hohipera ia inaianei.She's at the hospital now.

title: Tāwhirimātea
kupu_ingarihi: God of the wind and storms
desc:
Ko Tāwhirimātea te atua o te hau me ngā āwhā.
Tāwhirimātea is the god of the wind and storms.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

Also see hau.

Ngā tohu a Tāwhirimātea.
The weather – the signs of Tāwhirimātea.

Learn more at Te Ara.

title: kōwhiti, kōwhitiwhiti
desc:
E kōwhiti ana te tamaiti nā i ngā kuku.
The mussels are being shelled by that child by you.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: ua
desc:
E ua ana ki waho. 
It’s raining outside. 
- this is an example of an active sentence
Titiro ai au ki te ua. 
I watch the rain.
- this example uses "ai" for customary action
E whakamākūtia ana ngā kākahu e te ua.
The clothes are being drenched by the rain.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

In the first example ua is used as a verb; in the second and third ua is used as a noun.

title: hukapapa
desc:
E tākaro ana ngā tamariki ki te hukapapa. The children are playing with the snow.- this is an example of an active sentence
Also see hukarere.

title: hukarere
desc:
Nā te hukarere au i makariri ai.It was the snow that made me cold.- this is an example of the agent emphatic
Also see hukapapa.

title: tiakareti wera
desc:
Inu ai au i te tiakareti wera i te makariri. 
I drink hot chocolate in winter.
- this example uses "ai" for customary action

title: hōtoke
desc:
Ko te marama o Pipiri te tīmatanga o te hōtoke.
The month of June is the beginning of winter.
- this is an example of an equative sentence
Also see makariri.

title: i te nuinga o te wā
kupu_maori: i te nuinga o te wā
desc:
I te nuinga o te wā, hoki mai ai ia i mua i te ono karaka.
Most of the time, she comes back before six o'clock.
- this example uses "ai" for customary action

title: ka taka te wā
desc:
Ka taka te wā, ka moe te pēpi.After a while, the baby went to sleep.
See also nāwai rā.

title: pōtae
desc:
Tikina tō pōtae.
Fetch your hat.
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form

title: Hōngongoi (2)
desc:
He marama pai a Hōngongoi kia kokotia ai ngā rohi.July is a good month to prune the roses.- this is an example of a classifying sentence
Me kokoti ngā rohi i a Hōngongoi. The roses should be pruned in July.

title: mai rā anō
kupu_ingarihi: for as long as anyone can remember

title: hua
desc:
He hua reka tēnei. 
This is a delicious egg. 
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: kātahi anō
desc:
Kātahi anō māua ka tae mai i tāwāhi.
We (two exclusive) have only just arrived from overseas.
Note the reverse ordering of the subject (māua) and the tense marker (ka) following kātahi anō.

title: tārai(tia)
kupu_ingarihi: dress, shape, fashion timber with an adze

title: kō atu
kupu_ingarihi: farther side of a distant object

title: horoi(a)
desc:
Me horoi koe, e te tau!
You should wash, my darling!
- this is an example of using Me - Should

Ka horoi au i ngā kākahu.
I will wash the clothes.
- this is an example of an active sentence


Ia rā, ia rā, oho ai au ki te horoi i ngā kākahu.
Every day, I get up to wash the clothes.
- this example uses "ai" for customary action

title: whare horoi kākahu
desc:
I haere au ki te whare horoi kākahu.
I went to the laundry.
- this is an example of an active sentence
He pūngāwerewere kei roto i tōku whare horoi kākahu.
There are spiders in my laundry.

Another word for this is rūma horoi kākahu.

title: wehewehe(a)
desc:
Ka wehewehea ngā kākahu i runga anō i te tae.
The clothes will be sorted according to colour.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
Māu te kete kākahu e wehewehe.
You will sort the clothes basket.
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

title: uta(ina)
desc:
I utaina e au ngā kākahu ki roto i te mīhini horoi.
The clothes were loaded into the washing machine by me.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
Ka uta au i ngā kākahu ki te kete kākahu.
I will load the clothes into the clothes basket
- this is an example of an active sentence

Note: uta also means ashore.

title: whakairi(a)
desc:
E whakairi ana taku tāne i ngā kākahu horoi.
My husband is hanging the washing.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Mā taku hoa tāne ngā kākahu horoi e whakairi.
My boyfriend will hang the washing.
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

title: whāwhai
desc: Kei te whāwhai atu rāua ki waho kia tīkina ngā kākahu horoi.They are rushing outside to fetch the washing.- this is an example of an active sentence

title: tiki (tīkina)
desc:
Tīkina ōu kākahu paru!
Fetch your dirty clothes!
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form
Kua tīkina ngā kākahu horoi e ngā tamariki.
The clean clothes have been fetched by the children.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
Ka tiki au i te kete kākahu.
I will fetch the clothes basket.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: paru
desc:
Auē! Kātahi te kākahu paru!
Auē! How dirty the clothes are!
Ka horoi au i ngā kākahu paru.
I will wash the dirty clothes.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: kāore e kore
desc:
Kāore e kore, ka mauria mai e ia tāna hoa wahine.Without a doubt, he will bring his girlfriend.- this is an example of a passive sentence
Kāore e kore, ka patai ia i a ia ā tēnei pō.Without a doubt, he will ask her tonight.- this is an example of an active sentence

title: i a (s) e (v) ana
desc:
I a ia e inu ana, i kite ia i te manu.While she was drinking, she saw the bird.- this is an example of an active sentence
I a au e waiata ana, i mahara ki te umu.While I was singing, I remembered the oven.- this is an example of an active sentence

title: e hia kē mai nei
desc:
Tokohia kē mai nei ngā tāngata e tae mai ana mō te kai!
What a lot of people are arriving for the food!

E hia kē mai nei ngā kōura!
What a lot of crayfish!

title: kāore i roa, kāore e roa
kupu_maori: kāore i roa, kāore e roa
kupu_ingarihi: it wasn't long, it won't be long
desc:
Kāore i roa kua wareware te parāoa i a ia.It wasn't long before he had forgotten the bread.- this is an example of a stative sentence
Kāore e roa, ka tae mai ia e mauria ana tōu koti.It won't be long before she arrives bringing with her your coat.- this is an example of an active sentence

title: i te (tau / marama...) kua pahure ake nei
kupu_maori: i te (tau / marama...) kua pahure ake nei
desc:
I te tau kua pahure ake nei, kaore au i mōhio ki te reo.Last year, I didn't know te reo.
See also i tērā (wiki/tau) for a simpler construction.

title: neke atu i te
desc: Neke atu i te tekau tara te utu o te kai.The food costs more than ten dollars.

title: me te mea nei
desc:
Me te mea nei ka haere au ki Ōtepoti ā te Rāmere.It looks as if I'll go to Dunedin on Friday.- this is an example of an active sentence
Also see ko te āhua nei.

title: i muri mai i tērā
desc: I muri mai i tērā, i tunu ia i ētahi tōhi.After that, he made some toast.

title: ka (v) ana (s)
desc: Ka haere ana au ki te toa, ka kitea tōu tungane.When I went to the shop, I saw your brother.

title: ao ake i te ata
desc: Ao ake i te ata, i oho ia i waenganui o ngā ngeru e rua.The next morning, she awoke between the two cats.

title: nāwai rā
desc:
Nāwai rā, kua nui haere ngā tipu.After a while, the plants had become bigger.
See also ka taka te wā.

title: ahakoa he aha
desc: Ka haere mai rātou ahakoa he aha.They (3+) will come no matter what.- this is an example of an active sentence

title: hau
desc:
Kei te pupuhi te hau.
The wind is blowing.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Kei te pūhia ngā kākahu e te hau.
The clothes are being blown by the wind.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
Also see Tāwhirimātea.

title: raranga
desc:
E ako ana au ki te raranga harakeke.
I am learning to weave flax.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Ka raranga ngā kuia i ngā kete.
The old women will weave the bags.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Nā te kōtiro ngā putiputi i raranga.
It was the girl who wove the flowers.
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

title: tapahi(a)
desc:
Hei te ata, ka tapahi koe i te harakeke.
You will cut the flax in the morning.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Kua tapahia kētia te harakeke e au.
The flax has already been cut by me.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
Kāore au e tapahi i te rito o te harakeke.
I will not cut the rito (inner shoot) of the flax.
- this is a negative verbal sentence

title: hui
desc:
E haere ana tātou ki te hui raranga.
We are going to the weaving meeting.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Mā te rangatira o te iwi te hui e tīmata ki te karakia.
The chief of the tribe will begin the meeting with the prayer.
- this is an example of the agent emphatic
Kei te papa tuatoru te hui ā te ahiahi nei. 
The meeting will be held on the third floor this afternoon. 
- this is an example of a locative sentence 

E hui ana a Rama rāua ko Pita ki te pātaka kōrero. 
Rama and Pita are meeting in the library. 
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: harakeke
desc:
Ka hoatu au i tāku putiputi harakeke tuatahi ki tōku hoa.
I will give/gift my first flax flower to my friend.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Kua tukua e au tāku putiputi harakeke tuatahi ki tōku hoa.
My first flax flower has been sent to my friend by me.
- this is an example of a passive sentence 

Two other words meaning give are hōmai and hoatu.

title: tītī
desc:
Ka haere au ki te toa hoko tītī ai.I will go to the shop to buy muttonbird.- this is an example of an active sentence- this example uses "ai" for additional information
Kua tae mai ngā tītī.The muttonbirds have arrived.- this is an example of an active sentence

title: manaaki(tia)
kupu_ingarihi: look after, care for, show respect or kindess to
desc:
Ka manaakitia te harakeke e au.
The flax will be looked after by me.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
Mā mātou koutou e manaaki.
We will take care of you.
- this is an example of the agent emphatic
Ka manaaki te tangata whenua i ngā manuhiri.
The people of the land/marae will care for the visitors.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: ngohengohe
desc:
He ngohengohe te harakeke.
The flax is soft.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

Hōmai te māripi hei whakangohengohete harakeke.
Pass the knife to soften the flax.
- this is an example of a command in simple active form

title: māripi
desc:
Ka tapahi au i te harakeke ki te māripi koi.
I will cut the flax with a sharp knife.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Kei hea te māripi?
Where's the knife?
- this example uses hea to ask where
Another word for knife is naihi.

title: kete
desc:
Nā te kōtiro te kete ātaahua i raranga.
It was the girl who wove the beautiful basket.
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

title: whiri(a)
desc:
I whiria te tū harakeke e te kuia.
The flax girdle was braided by the old woman.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
E whiri ana au i te kōnae.
I am braiding the food basket.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: kōnae
desc:
I te kōnae harakeke ngā rīwai.
The potatoes were in the flax basket.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

Kua raranga ngā tohunga i nga kōnae.
The experts have woven the baskets.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: whakairo(tia/ngia)
desc:
Kātahi ngā whakairo ātaahua i te marae o Te Ore Ore.
What beautiful carvings there are in Te Ore Ore Marae. 
I whakairotia ngā whakairo e ngā tohunga.
The carvings were carved by experts.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
Ka haere ngā kuia e mau kete whakairo ana ki te hui.
The old women will go to the meeting carrying their decorated bags.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: whakaako(na)
desc:
Ka whakaako au i te raranga harakeke ki a koe.
I will teach you to weave flax.
- this is an example of an active sentence
I whakaakona māua ki te raranga harakeke e tō māua kaiako.
We (2 exclusive) were taught to weave flax by our teacher.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: tunu(a)
desc:
E rua tekau meneti ngā tītī e tunua ana i roto it te umu.
The muttonbirds were roasted in the hot oven for twenty minutes.

Ka tunu au i te parāoa ā tēnei pō.
I'll bake the bread tonight.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: umu
desc:
Kei roto ngā kūmara i te umu.
The kumara are in the oven.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

The name Temuka (a town near Timaru) comes from "Te Umu Kaha" meaning "the (place of) strong ovens".

title: tapahi(a), tapatapahi(a)
desc:
E tapatapahia ana ngā aniana e ia. 
The onions are being diced by him.
- this is an example of a passive sentence 

I tīkina te māripi e ia, kātahi ka tapahi ia i te pāua.
He fetched the knife, then he chopped the pāua.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: hoko(na)
desc:
I hokona ngā ika e ia.
The fish were bought by him.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
Ka hoko ia i te inu.
She will buy the drink.
- this is an example of an active sentence

I haere au ki ngā toa hoko kai ai.
I went to the shops to buy food.
- this is an example of an active sentence
- this example uses "ai" for additional information

title: pouaka makariri - unused
desc:
Kei roto ngā ika i te pouaka makariri.
The fish are inside the fridge.
- this is an example of a locative sentence
Kei te pouaka makariri te tīhi.
The cheese is in the fridge.
- this is an example of a locative sentence
Kaua e huakina te pouaka makariri!
Don't open the refrigerator!
- this is an example use of Kaua e - Do not
Kaua e waiho te tatau o te pouaka makariri kia puare ana.
Don't leave the fridge door open.
- this is an example use of Kaua e - Do not
Literally "cold box".

title: reka
desc:
Tino reka te mīti!
The meat is yummy!

whakareka(tia) means to sweeten, for example:

Kua whakarekatia te inu.
The drink has been sweetened.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

He reka ake tāku aihikirimi i tāu. 
My icecream is yummier than yours. 
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: kakara
desc:
Tō kakara hoki!
You smell lovely!

title: purua
kupu_ingarihi: confine by means of a plug

title: paruauru
desc:
Nā te paruauru te oneone i taupoki.
It was the gardener who dug the garden.
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

title: taupoki(tia)
desc:
I taupokitia te oneone e te paruauru.
The soil was dug by the gardener.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
 E taupoki ana ia i te māra.
She's digging the garden.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: rongoā
desc:
I kohikohi ia i te kawakawa hei rongoā mō te māuiui o tāna tama.  
He collected kawakawa as a cure for his son's illness.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: māra
desc:
E toro mai ana ngā tūī ki te māra.
The tūī are visiting the garden.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: kāheru
desc:
Kei roto te kāheru i te wharau.
The spade is in the shed.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

title: tupu(ria), tipu(ria)
desc:
Kāore ngā putiputi e tupu i te marumaru.
The flowers will not flourish in the shade.
- this is a negative verbal sentence


Ka tipu te rito o te harakeke i tēnei marama.
The new shoots of flax will sprout this month.
- this is an example of an active sentence


Haere ki te whakamākū i ngā tipu.
Go water the seedlings.
- this is an example of a command in simple active form

title: huarākau
desc:
Kia toru ngā momo huarākau.
[Choose] three pieces of fruit.


Ko te panana tāku tūmomo huarākau pai rawa. 
Banana is my favourite type of fruit. 
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: pātītī
desc:
Ka tapahi au i te pātītī.
I will cut the grass.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Kua tapahia te pātītī e au.
The grass has been cut by me.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: whakatipu(a)
desc:
E whakatipua ana te pātītī e Papa-tū-ā-nuku.
The grass is being grown by Papa-tū-ā-nuku.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

Nā Maru te kūmara i whakatipu.
Maru grew the kūmara.
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

I whakatipu a Maru i te kūmara.
Maru grew the kūmara.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: marumaru
desc:
I noho au i raro i te marumaru o te pōhutukawa.
I sat under the shade of the pōhutukawa.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: putiputi
desc:
E hia kē mai nei ngā putiputi ātaahua i tēnei kōanga.
What a lot of beautiful flowers this spring.

title: wharau
desc:
E moe ana te paruauru i roto i te wharau.
The gardener is sleeping in the shed.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Kei roto te paruauru i te wharau. E moe ana ia.
The gardener is in the shed. He's sleeping.
- this is an example of a locative sentence - this is an example of an active sentence

title: pūngāwerewere
desc:
E huna ana te pūngāwerewere i roto i te pouaka rēta.
The spider is hiding in the letterbox.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: kākano
desc:
Kai ai ngā manu i ngā kākano o tēnei rākau hua.
The birds eat the seeds of this fruit tree.
- this example uses "ai" for customary action

title: whakatō(kia)
desc:
I whakatōkia ngā tipu e te paruauru.
The seedlings were planted by the gardener.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

Ka whakatō te paruauru i ngā tipu ā tērā wiki.
The gardener will plant the seedlings next week.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: mākū
desc:
Kei te mākū koe?
Are you wet?
- this is an example of a stative sentence
- this example uses tone of voice to ask a question

title: Pakokori
kupu_ingarihi: deck house of a large canoe

title: roro
kupu_ingarihi: the front end of the meeting house, porch
desc:
Haere ki te roro o te whare.
Go to the front of the house.
Me kuhu atu koe ki te roro o te whare i muri mai o tētahi pōwhiri.
You should enter through the entrance of the meeting house following a welcoming ceremony.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: Kainamu
kupu_ingarihi: to be within a little of

title: paparakauta
desc:
Me haere tahi tāua ki te paparakauta ā muri i te mahi!
We (2 incl) should go together to the pub after work!

title: whānako
desc:
He whānako tōu matua?  Nā te mea, kua tāhae ia i ngā whetu i te rangi, ā, i waihotia e ia i roto i ōu karu!
Is your father a thief?  Because he has stolen the stars from the sky and put them in your eyes!

title: whetū
Ka taea e au?
desc:
Ka taea e au te hoko inu māu?
Can I buy you a drink?
- learn how to use the kupu taea

title: ātahu
desc:
Kaua e waiho i tōu ātahu!  Ko au tērā!!
Don't leave your love charm behind!  That's me!!

title: wāhi
desc:
He aha tētahi kōtiro pēnā ki a koe i roto i tētahi wāhi pēnei ki tēnei?
What's a girl like you doing in a place like this?

title: waimarie
desc:
I'm so lucky to have laid eyes on you!
Ko tōku waimarie hoki ki te titiro ki a koe!

title: oho, whakaoho(a)
desc:
Kua oho mai koe.
You’re awake.
- this is an example of a stative sentence


Ka taea au te whakaoho e koe ā te whitu karaka?
Are you able to wake me at 7 o’clock?
- learn how to use the kupu taea

Oho ai au i te ono karaka i te ata.
I wake up at six o'clock in the morning.
- this example uses "ai" for customary action

title: hīrere
desc:
Ai! Kua pakaru te hīrere.
Ai! The shower has broken!
- this is an example of a stative sentence

E haere ana au ki te rūma horoi hīrere ai.
I'm going to the bathroom for a shower.
- this is an example of an active sentence
- this example uses "ai" to indicate purpose

title: parakuihi
desc:
Kua whakareri tāku tāne i te parakuihi.
My husband has prepared breakfast.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Nā taku tāne te parakuihi i whakareri!
My husband prepared breakfast!
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

title: whakakākahu(ria)
desc:
E whakakākahuana ia i a ia anō ki ōna kākahu tino pai.
He’s getting himself dressed in his best clothes.
- this is an example of an active sentence


Awhinatia tāu tuahine ki te whakakākahu i a ia anō!
Help your sister to get herself dressed!
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form


Also see whakamau.

title: kimi(hia)
desc:
E kimi ana a Manu i tāna waea pūkoro.
Manu is searching for his cell phone.
- this is an example of an active sentence


Kua kimihia tāna waea pūkoro i ngā wāhi katoa.
He has searched everywhere for his cell phone. 
(Literally, his cell phone has been searched for everywhere.)
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: kite(a)
desc:
Kua kitea e koe? Ko te aha? Ko tāku waea pūkoro?
Have you seen it? What? My cell phone?
- this is an example of a passive sentence


Kei te kite koe i ngā manu rā?
Can you see those birds?
(Literally, “Are you seeing the birds there?”)
- this is an example of an active sentence

Although kite is an experience verb, it always takes ‘i’ rather than ‘ki’.

Ka kite ā te pō nei!
See [you] tonight!
- this is an example of an active sentence

Ka kite au i a koe ā te pō nei.
I will see you tonight.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: kati(a)
desc:
Kua kati te kēti i a au.
I’ve closed the gate.
- this is an example of a stative sentence

Ka kati au i te kēti.
I will close the gate.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Kaua e wareware ki te kati i te tatau.
Don’t forget to close the door.
- this is an example use of Kaua e - Do not

title: pahikara
desc:
Ka haere au ki te mahi mā runga pahikara i tēnei rā.
I'll go to work by bicycle today.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Also see runga.

title: whakapai(ngia)
desc:
Kua whakapaingia tōu ruma?
Have [you] tidied your room?
- this is an example of a passive sentence

Kua whakapai au i te hīrere.
I’ve repaired the shower.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Also see whakatika(ina).

title: whakatika(ina)
desc:
Kua whakatika au i te moenga.
I've made the bed.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Whakatikaina ēnei rerenga!
Correct these sentences.
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form

Also see whakapai(ngia).

title: maumahara(tia)
desc:
Kāore au i maumahara ki te haora o te pahi tuatahi.
I can’t remember the time of the first bus.
- this is a negative verbal sentence

maumahara always takes ‘ki’ rather than ‘i’.

title: whaea
desc:
Ko Mereana tōku whaea.
Mereana is my mother.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: irāmutu
desc:
Ko tāku irāmutu ia.
She is my niece. (He is my nephew.)
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: mātāmua
desc:
Ko Hone te mātāmua.
Hone is the eldest sibling.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

Ko Joseph te mātaamua o āku tamariki.
Joseph is the eldest of my children.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: karaihe
desc:
E noho mārie ana ngā tamariki i roto i te karaihe.
The children are sitting patiently in the classroom.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: papa tākaro
desc:
I te ata e tākaro ana ngā tamariki i runga i te papa tākaro.
In the morning the children are playing on the playground.
- this is an example of an active sentence - this is an example of a locative sentence

title: kura
desc:
E haere ana koe ki te kura āpōpō.
You’re going to school tomorrow.
- this is an example of an active sentence

He pai tōku kura. 
My school is good. 
- this is an example of a classifying sentence 


Kāore e roa ka tīmata anō te kura.
It won’t be long until school starts again.

title: whutupōro
desc:
Kei te tākaro ngā tamariki i te whutupōro i runga i te papa tākaro.
The children play football on the playingfield.
- this is an example of an active sentence - this is an example of a locative sentence

title: kaiako
desc:
I whakaakona ngā tamariki e te kaiako.
The children were taught by the teacher.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

Ehara tērā wahine i te kaiako. 
That woman isn’t a teacher. 
- this is an example use of Ehara to negate an equative sentence 

He tūnga matua te mahi a ngā kaiako ki te whakaako i ā tātou  tamariki.
A teacher's job is important as they are the ones who teach our  children.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence 

Hoatu te āporo ki te kaiako.
Give the apple to the teacher.

title: ako(na)
desc:
Kua ako a Mere i te waiata.
Mere has learnt the song.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Ka ako te kaiako i ngā tauira.
The teacher will teach the students.
- this is an example of an active sentence

‘whakaako’ is also frequently used for ‘teach’.

title: pukapuka
desc:
Whakahokia ngā pukapuka.
Put the books away.
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form


Nāku te pukapuka hītori i pānui i te Pātaka Kōrero. 
I read the history book in the library. 
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

title: pene rākau
desc:
Kua wareware taku pene rākau i ahau.
My pencil was forgotten by me. (I forgot my pencil)
- this is an example of a stative sentence
I whakakoia te pene rākau e taku hoa.
The pencil was sharpened by my friend.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: tikanga pāngarau
desc:
Ia rā ia rā ka whakaharatau mātou i ō mātou tikanga pāngarau.
Everyday we (3+ exclusive) practice our mathematics.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: tuhituhi(a)
desc:
I tēnei rā ka tuhituhi tātou i tētahi kōrero pūrākau mō ō tātou whānau.
Today we (3+ inclusive) will write a story about our (3+ inclusive) families.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: kōrero pūrākau
desc:
I pānui au i tāku kōrero pūrākau ki te karaihe.
I read my story to the class.
- this is an example of an active sentence
He pai tāku kōrero pūrākau ki tōku kaiako.
My teacher liked my story.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: pere
desc:
Kia whakarongo mātou i te pere ka mohio mātou ko te wā tākaro ināianei.
When we (3+ exclusive) hear the bell we know it is now playtime.

title: tina
desc:
He aha hei tina māu, e te tau?
What would you like for lunch, my darling?
- this example uses he aha to ask what

title: tēpu tuhituhi
desc:
I runga ngā pukapuka i te tēpu tuhituhi.
The books were on the desk.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

title: pūngakupu
desc:
I whakatikaina tāku pūngakupu e tōku kaiako.
My spelling was corrected by my teacher.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
Ka whakatika au i tāku pūngakupu.
I will correct my spelling.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: kākahu orite
desc:
Mauria ai te kākahu orite e te tauira.
The uniform is worn by the student.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
- this example uses "ai" for customary action

title: mahi kāinga
desc:
Ā te pō nei ka mahi au i tāku mahi kāinga.
This evening I will do my homework.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Kāore anō au kia mahi i tāku mahi kāinga.
I haven't done my homework.
- this is a negative verbal sentence

title: mōhiti
desc:
Kua mahue ōku mōhiti i a au.
I've left my glasses behind.
- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: whakamātautau
desc:
Āpōpō ka whakauru au ki ngā whakamātautau.
Tommorrow I will sit exams.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: tauira
desc:
E waiatatia ana ngā waiata e ngā tauira.
The songs are being sung by the students.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
Te tokomaha o ngā tauira kei tēnei kura! 
What a lot of students at this school!

title: karanga(tia)
desc:
Nā taua kuia te karanga i karanga.
The elderly woman called the call of welcome.
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

Kua karangatia te ope whakaeke e te kuia.
The ascending group have been called by the elderly woman.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

Ko te karanga te mahi tuatahi o te pōwhiri.
The karanga is the very first thing to happen at a welcoming ceremony.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: tono(a)
kupu_ingarihi: to send, command, ask for, request, demand, apply for
desc:
Mā koutou ngā pānui e tono atu ki ngā kaimahi. 
You (3/+) will send the notices out to the workers. 
- this is an example of the agent emphatic 

Kua tonoa kētia atu ngā pānui e mātou. 
The notices have already been sent out by us (3/+ exclusive). 
- this is an example of a passive sentence 

E tono ana ia kia haere ia ki te whakatā. 
He is requesting to go for a break. 
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: harirū(tia)
desc:
Kāore tātou e harirū, ka hongi kē.
We won’t shake hands, we’ll press noses instead.
- this is a negative verbal sentence

Ā muri i ngā kōrero, ka harirū ā ka hongi ngā rōpū e rua.
After the speeches, the two groups will shake hands and press noses.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: hokomaha
desc:
Kei te haere au ki te hokomaha.
I’m going to the supermarket.
- this is an example of an active sentence


Kei te haere ia ki te hokomaha ki te hoko i ngā kai.
He’s going to the supermarket to buy food.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Kei te haere ia ki te hokomaha hoko kai ai.
He’s going to the supermarket to buy food.
- this is an example of an active sentence 
- this example uses "ai" for additional information

title: torore
desc:
I utaina e au ngā kai ki roto i te torore.
The food was loaded into the trolley by me.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: utu
desc:
He aha te utu o tēnei āporo?
What's the price of this apple?
- this example uses he aha to ask what

title: kāri nama
desc:
I hokona e au ki tāku kari nama.
I paid with my credit card.
- this is an example of a passive sentence 

Kei roto tāku kāri nama i tāku pāhi. 
My credit card is in my wallet.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

title: e te tau
desc:
E te tau, kei runga noa atu koe!
Babe, you’re amazing!


Haramai, e te tau!
Come here, my darling!
- this is an example of a command in simple active form

title: matapihi
desc:
I tītiro ia ki ngā kākahu ātaahua i roto i te matapihi o te toa.
She looked at the beautiful dresses in the shop window.
- this is an example of an active sentence
He aha te utu o tēnei kurī i roto i te matapihi o te toa?
What's the price of this dog in the shop window?
- this example uses he aha to ask what

title: taonga tākaro
desc:
E tirohia ana ngā taonga tākaro ki te toa e ngā tamariki.
The toys in the shop are being looked at by the children.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: whakamau(a)
desc:
Ka whakamau au i ngā hū?
May I try on the shoes?
- this is an example of an active sentence


I whakamaua ngā hū e au.
The shoes were tried on by me.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

Another word for try on is kuhu(na).

Also see whakakākahu.

title: toa
desc:
Ka haere ngā tamariki ki te toa.
The children will go to the shop.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Me haere koe ki te toa!
You should go to the shop!
- this is an example of using Me - Should

Another word for shop is hoko.

title: rārangi
desc:
E tatari ana au ki te rārangi kia hoko ai i ōku hū.
I am waiting in the queue to pay for my shoes.
- this is an example of an active sentence 
- this example uses "ai" to indicate purpose
He rārangi roa kei te toa.
It is a long queue at the shop.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence
Kāore au e whanga ana ki te rārangi.
I will not wait in the queue.
- this is a negative verbal sentence

title: moni
desc:
He rawaka āku moni mo āku hokonga.
I have enough money for my purchases.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence
Kua pau te moni i a au.
The money has been spent by me.
- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: taonga
desc:
Ka hoko au i tētahi taonga mā tāku tahu.
I will buy a gift for my love.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Ka hokona te taonga e koe.
The gift will be bought by you.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: tī hāte
desc:
Kei hea ngā tī hāte?
Where are the t-shirts?
- this example uses hea to ask where
E pīrangi ana koe ki tēnei tī hāte kōwhai?
Do you want this yellow t-shirt?
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: pane koti
desc:
He aha te rahi o tēnei pane koti?
What size is this skirt?
- this example uses he aha to ask what
Ka pīrangi au ki te hoko i tēnei pane koti whero.
I would like to buy this red skirt.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: ruruku(tia)
desc:
Māu e ruruku āku hokonga tēnā koa.
Please wrap my purchases.
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

I rurukutia ngā hokonga e ia.
The purchases were wrapped by him.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: pūhera
desc:
Kei te hari au i ngā pūhera ki te waka.
I am carrying the purchases to the car.
- this is an example of an active sentence
I tēnei rā, he maha ngā pūhera i hokona e au.
Today I bought many parcels.

Kua whakakopaina ngā pūhera e ngā kaihoko.
The parcels have been wrapped by the shop assistants.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: e mea ana koe
desc:
E mea ana koe me hoki mai au ki te kainga?
Are you suggesting that I should go home?
Kāo, e mea kē ana au me waea koe i tōu whaea.
No, I'm suggesting you should phone your Mother.

title: pokotiwha
desc:
Pokotiwha! Kua mahue au i te pahi.
Damn! I've been left behind by the bus. (I've missed the bus.)

title: tio
desc:
Kei te pai ngā tio ki a au.
I like oysters.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: ehara i te mea he aha, heoi anō
kupu_maori: ehara i te mea he aha, heoi anō
desc:
Ehara i te mea he aha, heoi anō, kua ngaro tōku kōti.
It's no big deal, but I've lost my coat.

title: hoea tō waka
desc:
Hoea tō waka, e hoa!
Go for it, mate!
Hoea tō waka!
Please yourself! (sarcastically)

title: Kāore he raru!
desc:
Kāore he raru!
No problem!

title: Te Wiki o te Reo Māori
kupu_maori: Te Wiki o te Reo Māori
desc:
It's Māori Language Week!

Answer the phone with Kia ora!

Use Te Reo Māori in your emails and wherever you think you might be understood.

Recommend He Kupu o te Rā to others using the link below.

title: ākuanei, ā kō ake nei, ā kō kō ake nei
kupu_maori: ākuanei, ā kō ake nei, ā kō kō ake nei
desc:
Me haere koe ki te mahi ākuanei.
You'd better go to work soon.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Ka hoki mai ia ā kō ake nei.
He'll be back soon.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: E hika mā
desc:
E hika mā!
Crikey!

title: ānei, ānā, ārā
kupu_ingarihi: here it is, there it is (by you), there it is (at a distance)

title: e
kupu_ingarihi: word which precedes numbers 2-9 when counting objects
desc:
E toru ngā paraihe niho. 
There are three toothbrushes.

title: nehu(a)
desc:
Ka tū, ka tangi, ka nehua te tūpāpaku.
They stand, they grieve, the body is buried.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
Kua nehua ia i te taha o tōna tāne.
She has been buried next to her husband.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: mihi
desc:
He mihi tērā ki te whānau whānui.
That was a greeting to the extended family.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

E tū ki te mihi.
Stand up to greet.
- this is an example of a command in simple active form

Mihi atu ki ōu kaumātua.
Greet your elders.
- this is an example of a command in simple active form

Kei te mihi te koroua ki ngā manuhiri.
The elderly man is greeting the visitors.
- this is an example of an active sentence

He pai tā te koroua mihi.
The elderly man’s greeting was appropriate.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: hoki(a)
desc:
E hoki ki tōu maunga kia pūrea ai koe e ngā hau a Tāwhirimātea.
Return to your mountain so that you may be refreshed by the winds of Tāwhirimātea.
- this is an example of a command in simple active form

Me hoki koe ki tōu ake marae ki te ako i te kawa.
You should return to your own marae to learn protocol.
- this is an example of using Me - Should

He whaea ahau, he kaiwhakahaere hoki.
I am a mother and also an administrative assistant.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: i ngā rā o mua
kupu_ingarihi: in days gone by/ in the past

title: marama
desc:
Ka whiti te marama i te pō.
The moon shines at night.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: mau (ria)
kupu_ingarihi: to attach, to hold, to wear

title: rā
desc:
Ia rā, ia rā, ka haere au ki te kura. 
Every day I go to school. 
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: reo
desc:
Me kōrero tātou i te reo Māori i te kāinga. 
We (3/+inclusive) should speak the Māori language at home. 
- this is an example of using Me - Should

title: rongo (rangona)
desc:
Kua rongo rātou i te kai. 
They (3/+) have tasted the food. 
- this is an example of an active sentence

rongo using takes ‘i’ but can sometimes take ‘ki’.

Kua rangona e koe tērā harurutanga?
Did you hear that resounding sound?
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: tae
desc:
He aha te tae o tōu whare? 
What is the colour of your house? 
- this example uses he aha to ask what

title: taea
kupu_ingarihi: to be able to, capable of
desc:
Ka taea e au ngā tītī te tunu.
I am able to cook the muttonbird.
- learn how to use the kupu taea

title: tohu (a)
kupu_ingarihi: to point out, to identify (verbs)/ sign, symbol (nouns)

title: wiki
desc:
Ko tēnei te wiki o te reo Māori. 
This week is Māori language week. (This is the week of Māori language.) 
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: maranga
desc:
E oho. Maranga!
Wake up. Get up!
- this is an example of a command in simple active form

title: taihoa
desc:
Taihoa, ka tīmata ai tātou.
Wait and we’ll begin.

title: moe
desc:
E moe, e te tau.
Go to sleep, my darling.
- this is an example of a command in simple active form


Kei te moe ia i tōna moenga. 
He’s sleeping on his bed. 
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: tuhi(a)
desc:
Nāu tēnei i tuhi?
Did you write this?
- this example uses tone of voice to ask a question

title: inu(mia)
desc:
He inu māu?
Would you like a drink?
- this example uses tone of voice to ask a question

title: tīmata
desc:
Āhea te hui e tīmata ai? 
What time will the meeting start? 
- this example uses āhea to ask when 

Ā te rua karaka te hui e tīmata ai. 
The meeting will begin at 2 o’clock.

title: pātai(tia)
desc:
He pātai pai tēnā. 
That’s a good question. 
- this is an example of a classifying sentence 

Nāku te pātai i pātai. 
It was me who asked the question. 
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

title: waiata(tia)
desc:
Māku te waiata e waiata hei tautoko.
I will sing the song as support.
- this is an example of the agent emphatic
Ā muri i ngā whaikōrero ka tū ngā tāngata ki te tautoko i te waiata a te kaikōrero.
After the main speeches the people will stand to support the speaker's song.

title: Mā hea?
kupu_ingarihi: How? (mode of transport/route) how will you go?

title: tūpāpaku
desc:
E tangihia ana te tūpāpaku e te whānau pani.
The deceased is being mourned for by the chief mourners.
- this is an example of a passive sentence 

Ā tōna wā, ka moe te tūpāpaku i tōna moenga roa ki te kōpū o Papatūānuku.
In time, the deceased will eternally rest in the womb of Papatūānuku.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: whānau pani
desc:
Ko te mahi a te whānau pani kia noho ki te taha o te tūpāpaku.
The job of the chief mourners is to sit with the deceased.

Related terms include whare pātae (for those who wear the symbols of grief, e.g., kawakawa and black clothing) and whare mate.

title: kawakawa
kupu_ingarihi: a plant, the leaves of which are worn by women as a sign of mourning
desc:
E mau ana ngā kuia i te rau kawakawa .
The kawakawa are being held by the elderly women.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Other related terms: peka kawakawa - branch, rau kawakawa - leaves, pare kawakawa - head adornment.
Hīpoki ana te pare kawakawa hei tohu i tōku mamae.
