The ornament of kawakawa leaves covers me as a symbol of my grief.

title: urupā
desc:
Ka haere tātou ki te urupā ākuanei.
We (3/+ inclusive) will go to the cemetery soon.
I mua i tōu wehenga atu i te urupā, me pure koe i a koe anō ki te wai hei whakanoa anō hoki i a koe.
Before you depart from the cemetery, you should cleanse yourself with water in order to release yourself from tapu.

title: aituā
desc:
He aituā tō tātou.
We have experienced a fatality (literally: a fatality is ours), i.e., someone has passed away.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: tua
desc:
Haere ki tua o te ārai.
Go beyond the veil of death. 

(Said by those in speeches to the deceased.)

title: hemo
desc:
Kei hea tā tātou mokai? Kua hemo kē!
Where's our pet gone? It's dead!
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: kōpū
desc:
Kua nui haere te mamae ki tōnā kōpū.
The pain has become intense within her belly.
- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: tanu(mia)
desc:
E tanu ana rātou i te tūpāpaku.
They (3+) are burying the deceased.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Ka tanumia te tūpāpaku ki tō tātou urupā.
The deceased will be buried at our (3/+inclusive) cemetery.
- this is an example of a passive sentence
I te nuinga o te wā, ka tanumia te tūpāpaku i te taha o tōna whānau i te urupā o ōna tīpuna.
Usually, the deceased will be buried near his loved ones in the same cemetery as his ancestors.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: heke(a)
desc:
E heke, e te tau!
Get down, my darling!
- this is an example of a command in simple active form


Kei te heke ngā roimata, kei te heke, kei te heke, kei te heke.
The tears are falling, they fall, they fall, they fall.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: moenga roa
kupu_ingarihi: long sleep, eternal rest - euphemism for when a person dies
desc:
Kua haere ia ki tōna moenga roa.
She has gone to her eternal rest.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: ope
desc:
Kei mua te ope i te marae.
The group is in front of the marae.
- this is an example of a locative sentence
Ka haramai ngā ope i wīwī i wāwā.
Parties of visitors come from all over.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: whare tauā
kupu_ingarihi: the place where the corpse lies
desc:
Kei te whare tauā ia.
He is in the whare tauā.
- this is an example of a locative sentence
Hei roto koe i te whare tauā noho mai ai.
You will be staying in the whare tauā.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

title: Tāne Mahuta
kupu_ingarihi: God of the forest and all that dwell therein, especially the birds
desc:
Ko Tāne Mahuta te atua o te ngahere me ngā oranga o roto.
Tāne Mahuta is the god of the forest and all life within it.
- this is an example of an equative sentence
Learn more at Te Ara and Wikipedia.

title: Papatūānuku
desc:
Ko Papatūānuku te whaea o te whenua.
Papatūānuku is the earth mother.
- this is an example of an equative sentence
Learn more at Te Ara.

title: Ranginui
desc:
Ko Ranginui te matua o te rangi.
Ranginui is the father of the sky.
- this is an example of an equative sentence
Learn more at Te Ara.

title: Tangaroa
kupu_ingarihi: God of the sea, rivers, lakes and all that live within them
desc:
Ko Tangaroa te atua o te moana, ngā awa, ngā roto me te oranga o roto.
Tangaroa is the god of the sea, rivers, lakes and all life within them.
- this is an example of an equative sentence
Learn more at Te Ara.

title: Rongo
desc:
Ko Rongo te atua o te rangimārie.
Rongo is the god of peace.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

Learn more at NZETC.

title: Tūmatauenga
desc:
Ko Tūmatauenga te atua o ngā pakanga.
Tūmatauenga is the god of war.
- this is an example of an equative sentence
Learn more at Te Ara.

title: Rūaumoko
desc:
Ko Rūaumoko te atua o ngā rū me ngā puia.
Rūaumoko is the god of earthquakes and volcanoes.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

Learn more at Te Ara.

title: Haumia-tiketike
desc:
Ko Haumia-tiketike te atua o te aruhe he kai matua nā te Māori. 
Haumia-tiketike is the god of the fernroot, a staple food of the Māori. 
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: Rongo mā Tāne
kupu_ingarihi: God of kumara and all cultivated foods
desc:
Ko Rongo mā Tāne te atua o te kūmara me ngā kai whakatō. 
Rongo mā Tāne is the god of kūmara and cultivated foods. 
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: Whiro
desc:
Ko Whiro te atua o te kino o te ao. 
Whiro is the origin of evil in the world.

title: raparapa
kupu_ingarihi: extension of the barge boards of the meeting house.
desc:
Ko te raparapa ngā matimati o ngā maihi.
The raparapa are the fingers of the maihi.
- this is an example of an equative sentence
Mā ngā kaiwhakatāpoi e āta titiro ngā raparapa, kāore rātou e waia ana ki tēnei.
The tourists will examine the raparapa, this is not something they are used to.
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

title: maihi
kupu_ingarihi: barge boards of the meeting house (gables)
desc:
Kei mua ngā maihi i te tuanui o te wharenui.
The maihi (barge boards) are facing the front on the roof of the meeting house.
- this is an example of a locative sentence
He rite tonu ngā maihi o te whare ki ngā ringa o te tangata e torotoro ana.
The maihi are like outstretched arms of a person.

title: koruru
kupu_ingarihi: carved head at the apex of the meeting house
desc:
Ko te koruru te ūpoko o te tipuna o te wharenui.
The koruru is the head of the ancestor of the meeting house.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: tāhuhu
kupu_ingarihi: the main ridge-pole of the meeting house
desc:
E iri ana ngā pūrākau o te whare i te tāhuhu, ko te pātaka kōrero o te wharenui.
The stories of the house are hanging in the tāhuhu, the library of the meeting house. (The tāhuhu hold the traditional stories, like a library.)
- this is an example of an active sentence - this is an example of an equative sentence

title: tekoteko
kupu_ingarihi: carved figure at the apex of the meeting house
desc:
Ko te tekoteko te whakairo kei te tāuru o te wharenui.
The tekoteko is the carving at the top of the meeting house.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: whare whakairo
desc:
He maha ngā whakairo o ngā tīpuna i tēnei whare whakairo.
There are many carvings of ancestors in this carved house.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: wharenui
desc:
Te ātaahua hoki o tō tātou wharenui!
Our meeting house is extremely beautiful!
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: poupou
kupu_ingarihi: upright slabs forming the solid part of the walls of a meeting house, usually carved into figures
desc:
He tino kaha ngā poupou o ngā wharenui.
The poupou of meeting houses are extremely strong.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: wharekai
desc:
Haere atu ki te wharekai kai ai.
Go to the wharekai to eat.
- this is an example of a command in simple active form

title: wharepaku
desc:
Kei te pīrangi te tamaiti ki te haere ki te wharepaku.
The child wants to go to the toilet.
- this is an example of an active sentence
Mā kōrua te wharepaku e whakapai. 
You (2) will clean the toilet. 
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

title: paepae
kupu_ingarihi: bench at the front of the meeting house, front row of seats
desc:
Ka noho ngā kaikōrero ki te paepae whaikōrero ai.
The main speakers sit on the paepae in order to give the main speeches.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: marae ātea
kupu_ingarihi: the open space in the front of the meeting house
desc:
Me hui tātou ki te marae ātea ā te rua karaka .
We (3+ inclusive) should meet at the marae ātea at two o’clock.
- this is an example of using Me - Should

title: mahau
kupu_ingarihi: the porch of the meeting house
desc:
Waiho ōu hū ki te mahau.
Leave your shoes in the mahau.
- this is an example of a command in simple active form

title: kuia
desc:
Ko te karanga te mahi a ngā kuia.
The call of welcome is the job of the elderly women.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

I te nuinga o te wā, mā ngā kuia e karanga.
Most of the time, the karanga is done by the elderly women.

title: kaumātua
desc:
He kaumātua ia.
She is an elder.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

Ko ngā kaumātua ngā tāonga o te ao Māori.
The elderly people are the treasures of the Māori world.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: koroua
desc:
Kei muri te koroua i te marae.
The elderly man is behind the marae.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

I te nuinga o te wā, ko tā te koroua, he whaikōrero. 
Most of the time, the whaikōrero belong to the elderly men. (The whaikōrero are done by the elderly men.)

title: whaikōrero
kupu_ingarihi: to make a speech, main speech
desc:
E whaikōrero ana te koroua.
The elderly man is making a speech.
- this is an example of an active sentence

Kei te whakarongo au ki te whaikōrero.
I am listening to the main speech.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: karakia
desc:
Ka tīmata ngā hui ki te karakia. 
Meetings begin with a prayer.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: wero(hia)
kupu_ingarihi: to challenge (referring to traditional welcome to visitors), a challenge
desc:
I wero te toa i ngā manuhiri.
The warrior challenged the visitors.
- this is an example of an active sentence

He wero tērā nā ngā tāngata whenua.
That is a challenge from the people of the marae.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

I ētahi wā ka werohia ngā manuhiri ki ngā pōwhiri.
Sometimes visitors will be challenged at welcoming ceremonies.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: manuhiri
desc:
Ka pōwhiritia ngā manuhiri ki runga i te marae.
The visitors will be welcomed onto the marae.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

Eke ai ngā manuhiri tūārangi ki te marae i te Rā o Waitangi.
On Waitangi Day the visitors from afar go on to the marae.
- this example uses "ai" for customary action

title: whakaeke(a)
desc:
Ka karanga atu te rōpū whakaeke ki ngā tangata whenua.
The group ascending onto the marae calls back to the people of the land/marae.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: pōwhiri(tia) / pōhiri(tia)
desc:
Kāore anō ngā wāhine kia pōwhiri atu ki ngā manuhiri.
The women have not yet welcomed the guests.
- this is a negative verbal sentence

E pōwhiri ana rātou ki a mātou.
They are welcoming us.
- this is an example of an active sentence

He pai rawa atu taua pōwhiri ki a au.
I really enjoyed that pōwhiri.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: pūkana
kupu_ingarihi: fierce facial expressions used in actions songs and haka.
desc:
Ka pūkana mai ngā tāngata e haka ana.
The people who are doing the haka will do fierce facial expressions.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: tangata whenua
desc:
Kei te taha o te tangata whenua au i tēnei wā.
I’m on the side of the people of the marae this time.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

title: tikanga
desc:
Ko te tikanga matua o te marae ko te manaaki i ngā manuhiri.
The main custom of the marae is to care for the visitors.

title: kawa
desc:
Me mōhio koe ki te kawa o tōu marae.
You should know the protocol of your marae.
- this is an example of using Me - Should

title: takahi(a)
desc:
E takahia ana te whenua e ngā manuhiri.
The visitors are trampling the ground.

Kaua e takahi tikanga.
Do not trample on others’ customs.
- this is an example use of Kaua e - Do not

title: hākari(a)
desc:
Ka kai tahi tātou i te hākari.
We will eat the feast together.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: iwi
desc:
Tokomaha ngā tāngata o tērā iwi.
What a lot of people in that tribe.

Ko Kai Tahu te iwi.
Kai Tahu is the tribe.

Ko Ngāti Hāmoa te iwi.
I am Samoan. 
- this is an example of an equative sentence

Ko Ngāti Kahungunu tōku iwi.
Ngāti Kahungunu is my tribe.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: hongi
kupu_ingarihi: the pressing of noses (signifying unity in the mingling of one another's breath)
desc:
I hongi ngā manuhiri me ngā tāngata whenua.
The manuhiri pressed noses with the people of the marae.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: whakapono
desc:
Kāore te tamaiti i whakapono ki tā tōna hoa i kī ai.
The child didn‘t believe what his friend said.
- this is an example of using "t" possession
- this example includes a relative clause


E whakapono ana ia ki te Atua. 
She believes in God.
- this is an example of an active sentence

whakapono always takes ‘ki’ rather than ‘i’.

title: tūmanako
desc:
Ko te tūmanako, ka pai te rā.
It will hopefully be a good day (The hope is that it will be a good day).
- this is an example of an equative sentence

E tūmanako ana au kia hoki mai taku tau ākuanei.
I am hoping my darling will return home soon.
- this is an example of an active sentence

E tūmanako ana au ki te angitu kōrerotia ai e te kaitōrangapū.
I desire the successful outcome that was discussed by the politician.
- this is an example of an active sentence

tūmanako always takes ‘ki’ rather than ‘i’.

title: whare
desc:
Kei runga tō mātou whare i tētahi puke. 
Our (3/+ exclusive) house is on a hill. 
- this is an example of a locative sentence 

E rima ngā rūma moe o tōku whare. 
There are five bedrooms in my house.

title: kāinga
desc:
Me hoki ki te kāinga.
Let’s return (go back) home.
- this is an example of using Me - Should


Kei te kāinga au. 
I’m at home. 
- this is an example of a locative sentence

title: pouaka whakaata
desc:
Māku te pouaka whakaata e whakakā. 
I will turn on the television. 
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

title: rūma moe
desc:
Haere ki tōu rūma moe! 
Go to your bedroom! 
- this is an example of a command in simple active form

title: ārai
desc:
Katia ngā ārai. 
Shut the curtains. 
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form

title: tēpu
desc:
Kei waenganui ngā tūru i ngā tēpu. 
The chairs are in between the tables. 
- this is an example of a locative sentence
Me noho koe ki te tēpu i a koe e kai ana. 
You should sit at the table while you are eating. 
- this is an example of using Me - Should

title: tangata/tāngata
desc:
Tokoono ngā tāngata kei tōku whare e noho ana. 
There are six people living at my house. 

He tangata pai koe. 
You are a good person. 
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: kei
kupu_ingarihi: preposition, present time and place location - at, in
desc:
Kei hea koe?
Where are you?
- this example uses hea to ask where

Kei Disneyland au i nāianei!
I’m at Disneyland at the moment!
- this is an example of a locative sentence

title: huarahi
desc:
He aha te ingoa o tōu huarahi? 
What’s the name of your street? 
- this example uses he aha to ask what 

Kei te tū te waka i te huarahi. 
The car’s parked on the road. 
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: nui
desc:
Ka nui tēnā, e te tau.
That’s enough, my darling.

He tino nui te mahau o tōna whare. 
The deck at her house is very big. 
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: rohe
desc:
E noho ana au i te rohe o Pōneke. 
I am living in the Wellington area. 
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: hoa
desc:
Ka kite au i ōku hoa ki te kura. 
I will see my friends at school. 
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: pouaka makariri
desc:
Ka haere au ki te tiki miraka i te pouaka makariri. 
I will go and fetch the milk from the fridge. 
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: katoa
desc:
E haere ana ngā tamariki katoa ki waho. 
All of the children are going outside. 
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: te taha mauī
desc:
Kei te taha mauī o te rorohiko te pepa.
The paper is on the left-hand side of the computer.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

title: te taha matau
desc:
He aha kei te taha matau o te pouaka whakaata?
What’s on the right-hand side of the television?
- this example uses he aha to ask what

He kapu kei te taha matau o te pouaka whakaata.
A cup is on the right-hand side of the television.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: mātauranga
desc:
He mātauranga pai tōu. 
You have a good education. 
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: tika(ina)
kupu_ingarihi: to be right, correct, straight, in order
desc:
He tika tāu. 
You are right. (Yours is correct.) 

Kei te tika tāu whakautu. 
Your answer is correct. 
- this is an example of an active sentence 

Whakatikaina tōu rūma! 
Get your room in order (tidy your room up)! 
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form 

Kia tika āu raina.  
Make your lines straight. 
- this is an example of a command using kia

title: wānanga
desc:
Ā muri i te kura ka haere ngā tauira ki te whare wānanga. 
After school the students will go to university (the house of learning). 
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: hea
desc:
Kei hea koe?
Where are you?
- this is an example of a locative sentence

Kei te toa au.
I’m at the shop.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

I hea koe?
Where were you?
- this is an example of a locative sentence

I Taupō au.
I was in Taupō.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

title: whakamārama(tia)
desc:
E whakamārama ana te kaiako i te mahi ki ngā tamariki. 
The teacher is explaining the work to the children. 
- this is an example of an active sentence 

Kua whakamāramatia te mahi e te kaiako ki ngā tamariki. 
The work has been explained to the children by the teacher. 
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: uru
desc:
Kua uru ia ki te kura. 
She entered the school.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: wāhanga
desc:
He pai ake te wāhanga tuatahi o te pukapuka nei i te wāhanga tuarua. 
The first chapter is better than the second chapter of this book. 
- this is an example of a classifying sentence 

Ka tīmata taku tama i te kura ā te wāhanga tuarua o te tau. 
My son will start school in the second part of the year. 
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: rorohiko
desc:
Kei runga tāku rorohiko i tōku tēpu tari. 
My computer is on my desk. 
- this is an example of a locative sentence

title: īmēra
desc:
Tonoa atu tāu īmēra ki te kaikomihana. 
Send your email to the commissioner. 
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form

title: rangatira
desc:
Ko Māui te rangatira i te tari nei.
Māui is the boss at this department. 
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: whakahaere
kupu_ingarihi: to run something, manage, make something go
desc:
Mā wai tēnei hui e whakahaere? 
Who will run this meeting? 
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

title: tari
desc:
Haere ki tōku tari tatari ai. 
Go to my office and wait. 
- this is an example of a command in simple active form 

Ko ia te rangatira o tēnei tari. 
She’s the boss of this department. 
- this is an example of an equative sentence
I tōku tari au.
I was in my office. 
- this is an example of a locative sentence

title: take
kupu_ingarihi: reason, cause, origin, subject of discussion, root, stump
desc:
He aha te take o tāna karere? 
What was the reason for his call/message? 
- this example uses he aha to ask what 

Ko te rīpoata tuarua te take nei. 
The subject of discussion is the second report. 
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: kaimahi
desc:
He kaimahi pai koe! 
You are a good worker. 
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: karere
desc:
He karere māu. 
There is a message for you. 
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: wai
desc:
Inumia te wai! 
Drink the water! 
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form

title: momo
desc:
He aha tēnei momo kai? 
What type of food is this? 
- this example uses he aha to ask what

title: hapū
desc:
Ko Ngāti Hāmua tōku hapū.
Ngāti Hāmua is my sub-tribe.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: hanawiti
desc:
He hanawiti reka tēnā. 
That sandwich (you have/by you) is delicious. 
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: kapu
desc:
Ringihia mai te wai ki tāku kapu. 
Pour the water into my cup. 
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form

title: pereti
desc:
Kei hea tāna pereti? 
Where is his plate? 
- this example uses hea to ask where

title: hunga
desc:
Tuatahi me mihi ki te hunga mate. Tuarua me mihi ki te hunga ora.
Firstly you should acknowledge the dead (group of dead people). Secondly you should acknowledge the living (group of living people).

Ka wehe atu te hunga rā ākuanei.
That group of people (over there) will leave soon.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: awa
desc:
Ko Ruamāhanga te awa.
Ruamāhanga is the river.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

Ka whakawhiti tātou i te awa i te wāhi whāiti.
We’ll cross the river at the narrow part.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: maunga
desc:
Ko Rangitūmau te maunga.
Rangitūmau is the mountain.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: tūru
desc:
E noho ki runga i tōu tūru ka kai ai. 
Sit on your chair and eat. 
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: pai
desc:
Kia ora māmā mō te kai pai nei. 
Thanks mum for this good food.

title: moana
desc:
Ko te Moana-nui-ā-Kiwa te moana.
The Pacific Ocean is the ocean.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: tūranga waewae
desc:
Ko Wairarapa tōku tūranga waewae.
Wairarapa is my place to stand.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: hau kāinga
desc:
Hoki mai ki te hau kāinga.
Return home. (Return to your homeland.)
- this is an example of a command in simple active form

title: whānui
desc:
He mihi tēnei ki te whānau whānui.
This is a greeting to the extended (wider) family. 
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

Ko tōku whaea te tuara whānui o tō mātou whānau.
My mother is the (broad back) anchor of our family.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: huawhenua
desc:
Ko te kūmara tāku tūmomo huawhenua pai rawa. 
Kumara is my favourite type of vegetable. 
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: Pākehā
desc:
He Pākehā au.
I am a Pākehā.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: mīti
desc:
Ko te heihei te tūmomo mīti e kainga ana e ratou. 
Chicken is the type of meat being eaten by them. (The type of meat that is being eaten by them is chicken.) 
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: aihikirimi
desc:
Kia nui rawa atu tāku aihikirimi! 
Make my icecream huge!

title: tahi
desc:
Kotahi te tūru. 
There is one chair. 

Kotahi te tangata. 
There is one person.

title: rua
desc:
Kia rua ngā huka. 
Two sugars please. (Let it be two sugars.) 

Tokorua ngā wāhine kei tēnei rūma. 
There are two women in this room.

title: nō
desc:
Nō Wairarapa au.
I am from/belong to Wairarapa.

Nō is used to show which hapū, iwi or tribal area (rohe) you’re from.

title: toru
desc:
Kua toruō tau ināianei!
You’re three now!


E toru ngā mea. 
There are three things. 



Tokotoru ngā tama kei te papa tākaro. 
There are three boys at the playground.

title: whā
desc:
E whā ngā manu kei waho. 
There are four birds outside. 

Tokowhā ngā tāne kaha kei kōnei. 
There are four strong men here.

title: rima
desc:
Kua rere atu ngā manu e rima. 
The five birds have flown away. 
- this is an example of an active sentence 

Tokorima ngā tauira e katakata ana ki a ia. 
There are five students laughing at him.

title: ono
desc:
Tapahia kia ono ngā topenga. 
Cut it up into six slices. 
- this is an example of a passive sentence 

Tokoono ngā kōtiro kua haere. 
The six girls have gone.

title: whitu
desc:
Ko au te tangata tuawhitu i te whakataetae. 
I came seventh in the competition. (I was the seventh person in the competition.) 
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: waru
desc:
Ka kōrero te Pirihitini mō te ture tuawaru. 
The President will talk about the eighth amendment. 
- this is an example of an active sentence 

Tokowaru ngā pēpi kei tēnei kōhanga. 
There are eight babies at this creche.

title: mano
desc:
Ko tēnei te tau e rua mano mā iwa.
This year is 2009.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: iwa
desc:
E iwa ngā hoihō e oma atu ana. 
There are nine horses running away. 

Ko tēnei te hui tuaiwa ki konei. 
This is the ninth meeting here. 
- this is an example of an equative sentence 

Tokoiwa ngā tāngata i taua hui. 
There were nine people at that (aforementioned) meeting.

title: rau
desc:
Kotahi rau.
One hundred.

E rua rau.
Two hundred.

title: tekau
desc:
Tekau ngā whetu e tīrama ana i waho. 
There are ten stars twinkling outside. 

Tekau ngā pākete pihikete kei roto i te kāpata. 
There are ten packets of biscuits in the cupboard. 

Tekau ngā tāngata kei waho. 
There are ten people outside.

title: hia
desc:
E hia ngā pounamu? 
How many bottles are there? 

Tokohia ngā tāngata? 
How many people are there? 

Kia hia ngā huka? 
How many sugars?

title: tua-
kupu_ingarihi: prefix to  numbers 1-9 to create ordinal numbers: first, second, third etc.
desc:
Ko koe te tuatahi ki te kōrero i roto i tēnei karaihe.
You are the first to speak in this class.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: toko-
kupu_ingarihi: prefix to numbers 2-9 when counting people
desc:
Tokorima ngā tākuta o konei.
There are five doctors from here.

title: whiriwhiri (whiria)
desc:
He tohunga tōku kuia ki te whiriwhiri harakeke.
My grandmother is an expert at weaving flax.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence
Kua whiria kētia ngā whāriki e toru e tōku kui.
My nan already wove three mats.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: tākuta
desc:
He tākuta ahau.
I am a Doctor.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: hōhipera
desc:
Kei te hōhipera au e mahi ana.
I work at the hospital.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: rōia / pou toko ture
desc:
Ko au te rōia mō tēnei take.
I am the Lawyer for this case.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: kaiwhakahaere
desc:
Me haere koe ki te kaiwhakahaere.
You should go to the co-ordinator.
- this is an example of using Me - Should

title: kaiāwhina
desc:
He kaiāwhina ahau nō te kaiwhakahaere.
I am an assistant to the Director.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence

title: kaihoko
desc:
Pātai atu ki te kaihoko mō te utu.
Ask the salesperson for the price.
- this is an example of a command in simple active form

title: nēhi
desc:
Mai i tōku tamarikitanga pīrangi ai ahau ki te mahi nēhi.
Since childhood I have always wanted to be a nurse.

title: tari kāwanatanga
desc:
Kei te tari kāwanatanga au e mahi ana. 
I work in the public service.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: pirihimana
desc:
I aukatingia ahau e te pirihimana.
I was stopped by the police officer.
- this is an example of a passive sentence


Pātai atu ki te pirihimana.
Ask the police officer.
- this is an example of a command in simple active form

title: kaitiaki
desc:
Ko Tania te kaitiaki matua i tēnei rā.
Tania is the main caregiver today.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: kaiwhakatangitangi
desc:
E whakatangitangi ana te kaiwhakatangitangi i te kitā.
The musician is playing the guitar.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: ringawera
desc:
Tino reka te kai a te ringawera!
The chef’s meal was delicious!

title: kaitāmoko
desc:
Nā te kaitāmoko tōku moko i hoahoa.
The tattooist designed my tattoo.
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

title: Kirihimete
desc:
Kia pai tō Kirihimete.
Have a good Christmas.

title: Hana Kōkō
desc:
I heke iho a Hana Kōkō i tō mātou pākaiahi.
Santa Claus came down our chimney.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: Meri Kirihimete
desc:
Nāku i tuhi ki tōku kaiako “Meri Kirihimete nā āu tauira.”
I wrote to my teacher “Merry Christmas from your students.”
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

title: rākau Kirihimete
desc:
Kua whakanikotia kētia tō tātou rākau Kirihimete.
Our Christmas tree has already been decorated.
- this is an example of a passive sentence

title: koha
desc:
Nāku ngā koha i hanga i tēnei Kirihimete.
I made the presents for Christmas this year.
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

title: whakapaipaitanga
desc:
Kei runga ngā whakapaipaitanga i te rākau Kirihimete.
The decorations are on the Christmas tree.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

title: tōkena Kirihimete
desc:
Māku ngā tōkena Kirihimete e whakakī .
I will fill the Christmas stockings.
- this is an example of the agent emphatic

title: pepa ruruku
desc:
Rurukutia ngā koha ki te pepa ruruku tino ātaahua rawa atu.
Wrap the presents using the most beautiful wrapping paper.
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form

title: mārama Kirihimete
desc:
I kātoretore mai ngā mārama Kirihimete. 
The Christmas lights glimmered.
- this is an example of an active sentence

title: kāri Kirihimete
desc:
Kua oti i a koe āu kāri Kirihimete te tuhi?
Have you written your Christmas cards yet?
- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: hākari Kirihimete
desc:
Haere mai ki te kai i tō tātou hākari Kirihimete.
Come and eat our Christmas feast.
- this is an example of a command in simple active form

title: hīmene Kirihimete
desc:
Ko tēhea te hīmene Kirihimete e pīrangitia ana e koe ki te waiata?
Which Christmas carol do you want to sing?
- this example uses tēhea to ask which

title: anahera
desc:
Waihotia te anahera ki runga i te rākau Kirihimete.
Place the angel on top of the Christmas tree.
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form

title: waka
tipuna/tupuna / tīpuna/tūpuna
desc:
Ko Tōmuri Te Awa tōku tipuna.
Tōmuri Te Awa is my ancestor.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

The first vowel has a macron for the plural, e.g., tīpuna / tūpuna – ancestors.

title: matua whakaangi
desc:
Ko Tai tōku matua whakaangi.
Tai is my stepfather.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: whaea whakaangi
desc:
Ko Rosie tōku whaea whakaangi.
Rosie is my stepmother.
- this is an example of an equative sentence

title: wahine / wāhine
desc:
Ko Kelly tōku wahine.
Kelly is my wife.
- this is an example of an equative sentence



He wahine a Kelly.
Kelly is a woman.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence


Kei konei ngā wāhine.
The women are over here.
- this is an example of a locative sentence


He kaiako tērā wahine.
That woman is a teacher.

title: Ehara i te tī
desc:
Ehara i te tī
Y.O.L.O. – you only live once
- this is an example use of Ehara to negate an equative sentence

Derives from the whakataukī: 
“Ehara i te tī, e wana ake” – “unlike the tī (cordyline or cabbage tree), it will never bud.”

The various species of tī are noted for their ability to survive in spite of the serious prunings they receive. Even one cut to ground level normally produces young shoots. Moreover they can easily be transplanted from cuttings. Man is quite the opposite. Once he falls (dies), he will never rise again.
— Te Ao Hou, No. 17 (December 1956)

title: Mauri mahi, mauri ora
kupu_ingarihi: "Do the mahi, get the treats" (through work, we prosper)
desc:
Mauri mahi, mauri ora
"Do the mahi, get the treats" (through work, we prosper)
The full whakataukī (‘Māori proverb’) is: “Mauri mahi, mauri ora; mauri noho, mauri mate” – Industry begets prosperity; idleness begets poverty.

title: He kapu kawhe māu?
kupu_ingarihi: Would you like a cup of coffee?
desc:
He kapu kawhe māu?
Would you like a cup of coffee?
- this example uses tone of voice to ask a question


Potential replies:

“Āe, he kapu kawhe māku” – Yes, I'll have a cup of coffee.”
“Kāore, kei te pai.” – No, I'm good thanks.

title: Āhea tātou e wehe atu?
desc:
Āhea tātou e wehe atu?
When are we leaving?
- this example uses āhea to ask when


Example replies:

“Ā te rua karaka tātou e wehe atu” – We will leave at 2pm.

title: Kei te aha?
kupu_ingarihi: Up to? (What are you up to / doing?)
desc:
Kei te aha?
Up to? (What are you up to / doing?)


Some dialects say this to ask how you are. To respond: remove “aha” and replace with the action, e.g.

“Kei te mahi” – I’m working.
“Kei te pānui” – I’m reading.

title: Wehi nā!
desc:
Wehi nā!
OMG! Oh my gosh!

title: Kei te haere koe ki hea?

desc:
Kei te haere koe ki hea?
Where are you off to? Where are you going?
- this example uses tone of voice to ask a question


In response, remove the question word ‘hea’ and replace with the location, for example:

“Kei te haere au ki te pāti” – I'm going to the party.
“Kei te haere au ki Tāmaki Makaurau” – I'm going to Auckland.

title: e mua kai kai
desc:
This youth colloquial expression – FOMO – means “Fear Of Missing Out”.
“E mua kai kai” comes from the following whakatauki:


E mua kai kai, e muri kai huare.
Come early and eat food, come late (or not at all) and you may only eat your own spittle.


This is in some ways similar to “The early bird catches the worm”.

title: delete me now
desc: delete me now

title: Whāia te iti kahurangi!
kupu_ingarihi: Strive for something of great value!
desc:
Whāia te iti kahurangi!
Strive for something of great value!


This comes from the whakataukī: Whāia te iti kahurangi, ki te tuohu koe, me he maunga teitei, which means Seek the treasure that you value most dearly, if you bow your head, let it be to a lofty mountain.

This whakataukī is about perseverance and endurance. Refusing to let obstacles get in your way while striving to reach your goals.

title: mauri tau
desc:
E mauri tau ai koe me pūmanawa, whakahā.
In order to relax, you should take a deep breath in and exhale.
- this example uses "ai" to indicate purpose


He kaiako mauri tau tōku.
I have a really chill (calm / relaxed) teacher.

title: te ara āwhio
desc:
This comes from the following whakataukī:

“Ehara te ara horipū; haere koa i te ara āwhio.”
Go by the roundabout route rather than by the direct one.

“Sometimes an objective may best be obtained by finesse and indirect methods.” – Mead & Grove (2003).

title: Pukukata ana!
desc:
Pukukata ana!
I’m weak [with laughter]!


Laughing so hard you become weak.

title: Kia hora te marino, kia whakapapa pounamu te moana, kia tere te kārohirohi i mua i tō huarahi
kupu_maori: Kia hora te marino, kia whakapapa pounamu te moana, kia tere te kārohirohi i mua i tō huarahi
kupu_ingarihi: Well wishes, especially to a traveller
desc:
Kia hora te marino, kia whakapapa pounamu te moana, kia tere te kārohirohi i mua i tō huarahi.
May peace be widespread, may the sea glisten like greenstone, and may the shimmer of light guide you on your way.
A karakia / blessing on all who travel.

title: me ko Piwaiwaka
desc:
Me ko Piwaiwaka koe!
You’re such a tattletale!

This derives from the story of Māui and Hine-nui-te-pō (the goddess of death). The Pīwaiwaka (fantail) awoke Hine-nui-te-pō as Māui tried to defeat death. Therefore, the saying applies to a tattletale or one who tells on others.

title: Noho mata hī taua!
desc:
Noho mata hī taua!
Stay alert!

This comes from the whakataukī:
“E moe ana te mata hī tuna, ara ana te mata hī taua”
“The eel fisher’s eyes sleep, but the eyes of the warrior are awake.”
It tells us to be alert, ready and educated about what is going on in the world around us.

title: Hemo ana i te kata! (HAITK)
desc:
HAITK
LMAO

Literally “Dying from laughter”:

Hemo ana a Arini i te katakata
Arini is dying of laughter.

title: Mō te whakameamea!
desc:
Mō te whakameamea!
What a diva!

To say someone (right after they’ve done something) is such a …, you use the kīiwaha mō te … . Here whakameamea means to be so dramatic. So, “mō te whakameamea” means “Such a diva / soooo dramatic!”

title: Ka nui tēnā! (KNT)
desc:
KNT
TMI

title: Okea ururoatia!
desc:
Okea ururoatia!
Keep fighting! 
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form


This saying originates from the whakataukī:
“Kaua e mate wheke, mate ururoa”
which means, don’t die like the octopus (that gives up easily), die like the shark (that keeps on fighting). The meaning here is to keep fighting your fight (whatever it might be), like the shark.

title: He ika haehae kupenga
desc:
He ika haehae kupenga ia!
He’s such a stirrer!

This whakataukī means “A fish that tears the net.” It is in reference to someone who stirs up trouble or complains.

title: He toka tū moana
kupu_ingarihi: a rock standing firm in the sea
desc:
He toka tū moana ia!
She’s a rock!

This whakataukī refers to one who is steadfast and strong in their culture, beliefs and or position against all opposition. They are likened to the rock in the ocean that stands strong against all elements.

title: Nōku te hē
desc:
Nōku te hē.
My mistake. (The wrong belongs to me.)

title: He kura te tangata!
desc:
He kura te tangata!
We are all precious!

This whaktaukī is related to both the preciousness of the individual, and the contribution of the individual to the well-being of the group as a whole.

title: Hei aha atu māku!
desc:
Hei aha atu māku / māu / māna.

I / you / s/he doesn’t give a damn!

This kiiwaha is used to express not giving a *beep* about something.

title: He tou tīwaiwaka!
desc: The whakataukī He tou tīwaiwaka means a bottom like a tīwaiwaka (fantail). It refers to someone who can’t sit/stay still! A tīwaiwaka flutters about erratically to catch its prey.

title: ihu oneone
desc:
He ihu oneone ō tātou kaiako.
Our teachers are such hard workers.
- this is an example of a classifying sentence


‘Ihu oneone’ literally means ‘dirt nose’ and is used to describe an industrious person. The metaphor derives from those working the land back in the day: they wipe their sweat from their faces and their noses are marked with the dirt from their hard-working hands.

title: Ka hoki mai! / KHM
kupu_ingarihi: Be right back / BRB / Will return
desc:
Ka hoki mai!
Be right back


KHM
BRB


Literally ‘Will return!’

title: Mō te patu wairua!
desc:
Mō te patu wairua!
What a sad guy!

In general, to say someone (right after they’ve done something) is ‘such a …’ you use the kīwaha ‘mō te …’.
Here ‘patu wairua’ refers to someone who ‘hits your spirit’ or a ‘sad guy’.

title: Kua puta a pito!
desc:
Kua puta a Pito!
I‘m so full!

Literally “Pito (belly button) is popping out.”
Pito has been personified by using ‘a’ rather than ‘tōku’.

title: He uaua paraoa!
desc:
He uaua paraoa!
What a beast!


Used to describe someone who is muscular/strong.
This saying is derived from the whakataukī:
Ana tā te uaua paraoa.
Behold the strength of the sperm whale. I am powerful – attack me at your own peril.

title: He waka eke noa
kupu_ingarihi: We are all in this together / We got this, fam!
desc:
He waka eke noa.
We are all in this together / We got this, fam!

This whakataukī has several meanings, one of which is “a waka we are all in together” – we are all in this together – we rise together, fall together, work together, keep going together.

title: Mō taku hē!
desc:
Mō taku hē!
I’m sorry! My bad!

title: Kua pau te hau!
desc:
Kua pau te hau!
I’m exhausted!
- this is an example of a stative sentence

title: Tūwhitia te hopo, mairangatia te angitū!
kupu_maori: Tūwhitia te hopo, mairangatia te angitū!
kupu_ingarihi: Feel the fear and do it anyway!
desc:
Tūwhitia te hopo, mairangatia te angitū!
Feel the fear and do it anyway!
- this is an example of a command in simple passive form


A more literal translation is: Tūwhitia te hopo – eliminate the negative; mairangitia te angitū – accentuate the positive.

title: Namunamuā!
desc:
Namunamuā!
Yummy!

Namunamuā means ‘flavour’.

title: He kanohi kitea, ka hoki ngā mahara.
kupu_maori: He kanohi kitea, ka hoki ngā mahara.
kupu_ingarihi: A familiar face stirs the memory.
desc:
He kanohi kitea, ka hoki ngā mahara.
A familiar face stirs the memory.

title: Kua pau te wā. Kei a au te wā.
kupu_maori: Kua pau te wā. Kei a au te wā.
desc:
Kua pau te wā. Kei a au te wā.
Time is up. My turn.
- this is an example of a stative sentence - this is an example of a locative sentence

title: Kāore he painga i a koe mō te whakakatakata!
kupu_maori: Kāore he painga i a koe mō te whakakatakata!
kupu_ingarihi: No one beats you at being funny!
desc:
Kāore he painga i a koe mō te whakakatakata!
No one beats you at being funny!


The structure of this sentence is:
     Kāore he painga i a … mō te …
     There is no one better than … at …


Kāore he painga i a Adrienne mō te whakahaere.
There’s no one better than Adrienne at organising.

title: Kei tua o Tāwauwau ia.
kupu_ingarihi: He/she is off with the fairies.
desc:
Kei tua o Tāwauwau ia.
He/she is off with the fairies.
- this is an example of a locative sentence

​Tāwauwau is an unspecified distant place.
